choices.text: Increase of lipid synthesis by adipose tissue
Downregulation of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors in the liver
Inhibition HMG-CoA reductase activity in the liver

questions.text: A 24 year old woman suffering from familial hypertriglyceridemia was screened with a blood lipid profile during a routine visit. Relevant laboratory test results were total cholesterol 170 mg/dL, triglycerides 1230 mg/dL. A suitable lipid-lowering drug was prescribed by her physician. Which of the following is the most likely the mechanism of action of that prescribed drug in the reduction of triglycerides?
questions.solution:
• Fibrates, such as fenofibrate or gemfibrozil, are the most appropriate drugs for treating severe hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides >1000 mg/dL).
  • They primarily work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor α (PPARα), which enhances lipoprotein lipase synthesis.
  • This enzyme hydrolyzes triglycerides in very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL), reducing circulating triglyceride levels by 20-50%.
  • Fibrates also decrease hepatic triglyceride synthesis and increase LDL receptor expression, contributing to a 10-15% reduction in LDL cholesterol and a similar increase in HDL cholesterol.

Summary of Anti-Dyslipidemic drugs:

Explanation of other options:

Increase in lipid synthesis by adipose tissue (Option A): Increasing lipid synthesis would exacerbate hypertriglyceridemia by promoting triglyceride storage, which is counterproductive in this condition.

Downregulation of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors in the liver (Option B): Downregulating LDL receptors would reduce LDL uptake by the liver, increasing circulating LDL levels, which is not the primary mechanism for triglyceride reduction. Fibrates enhance LDL receptor expression.

Inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase activity in the liver (Option C): This is the mechanism of statins, which primarily lower LDL cholesterol by inhibiting cholesterol synthesis. While statins may have a modest effect on triglycerides, they are not the first-line treatment for severe hypertriglyceridemia.

Key takeaway

The fibrates primarily activate lipoprotein lipase, which is a key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL, resulting in a lowering of circulating triglycerides.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a sensation of dryness and grittiness in both eyes, which worsens throughout the day. She reports a history of rheumatoid arthritis and uses a computer for extended periods. On examination, the tear break-up time is decreased, and there is conjunctival hyperemia. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms of dryness, grittiness, decreased tear break-up time, and conjunctival hyperemia, combined with rheumatoid arthritis and prolonged screen time, indicate dry eye disease (keratoconjunctivitis sicca).
  • Artificial tears are the first-line treatment to lubricate the ocular surface, relieve symptoms, and prevent corneal damage.
  • Lifestyle modifications (e.g., screen breaks, humidifiers) complement this therapy.
  • Schirmer's test and tear break-up time (TBUT) confirm the diagnosis.

Dry Eye Disease (DED)/Keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

  • It is a condition where the eyes do not produce enough tears or the tears evaporate too quickly, leading to inflammation and damage to the ocular surface.

Etiology and Risk Factors:

  • Inadequate Tear Production: Associated with conditions such as Sjögren's syndrome, aging, or certain medications.
  • Increased Tear Evaporation: Often due to environmental factors, such as dry climates or excessive screen time, and eyelid disorders like meibomian gland dysfunction.
  • Hormonal Changes: Menopause, pregnancy, or hormonal therapies.
  • Autoimmune Disorders: Sjögren's syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Systemic Diseases: Diabetes and thyroid disorders.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Dryness: Sensation of dryness or grittiness in the eyes.
    • Redness: Hyperemia of the conjunctiva.
    • Burning: Burning or stinging sensation.
    • Foreign Body Sensation: Feeling as if something is in the eye.
    • Visual Disturbances: Blurred vision, particularly with prolonged reading or computer use.
  • Signs:
    • Tear Film Instability: Observed during slit-lamp examination.
    • Conjunctival Hyperemia: Redness of the conjunctiva.
    • Corneal Staining: Using fluorescein dye to highlight areas of dryness or damage.
    • Meibomian Gland Dysfunction: Gland expression and examination may show blocked glands.

Diagnosis:

  • Patient History: Assessment of symptoms and contributing factors.
  • Ocular Surface Evaluation:
    • Schirmer's Test: Measures tear production.
    • Tear Break-Up Time (TBUT): Assesses the stability of the tear film.
    • Fluorescein Staining: Identifies areas of corneal damage or dryness.
  • Meibography: Imaging of meibomian glands to evaluate gland function.

Management:

  • Artificial Tears: Over-the-counter lubricating eye drops to alleviate dryness.
  • Prescription Medications:
    • Anti-Inflammatory Drops: eg., cyclosporine A (Restasis) or lifitegrast (Xiidra).
    • Steroid Drops: For short-term use in severe cases to reduce inflammation.
  • Lifestyle Modifications:
    • Environmental Adjustments: Use of humidifiers and avoidance of direct airflow from fans or air conditioning.
    • Screen Time Management: Regular breaks and use of computer eyewear.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Punctal Plugs: To reduce tear drainage and increase tear film retention.
    • Scleral Lenses: Large-diameter lenses that trap moisture over the corneal surface.
  • Meibomian Gland Dysfunction Treatments: Warm compresses, eyelid hygiene, and massage.

Explanation of other options:

Oral Corticosteroids (Option A): While effective for reducing inflammation, they are not typically the first line of treatment for dry eyes due to potential systemic side effects.

Topical Antihistamines (Option B): Used primarily for allergic conjunctivitis, they do not address the underlying issues in dry eye disease.

Systemic Immunotherapy (Option D): Not commonly used for dry eyes unless there is an underlying systemic autoimmune condition that is unresponsive to other treatments.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled diabetes presents for a routine eye examination. Fundus examination reveals microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, and hard exudates, but no neovascularization is observed. Fluorescein angiography shows areas of capillary non-perfusion. Based on the findings, what is the most appropriate classification of this patient's retinopathy?
questions.solution:
The findings of microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, and capillary non-perfusion on fluorescein angiography indicate severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR).

NPDR(non proliferative diabetic retinopathy):

Pathophysiology:

  • NPDR results from damage to the small blood vessels in the retina due to chronic hyperglycemia, which leads to a breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier.
  • Key Features:
    • Microaneurysms: Outpouching of capillary walls.
    • Intraretinal hemorrhages: Leakage from damaged retinal vessels.
    • Hard Exudates: Lipid and protein deposits in the retina.
    • Cotton Wool Spots: Represent retinal nerve fiber layer infarcts.
    • Venous Beading: Abnormal dilation and beading of retinal veins, a sign of worsening ischemia.
    • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA): Shunt vessels that form due to capillary closure.

Classification of NPDR (ETDRS Classification):

  1. Mild NPDR:
    • Microaneurysms only.
  2. Moderate NPDR:
    • More severe retinal changes, such as hemorrhages and exudates, without meeting the criteria for severe NPDR.
  3. Severe NPDR(4-2-1 Rule):
    • Hemorrhages in all four quadrants.
    • Venous beading in two or more quadrants.
    • IRMA in one or more quadrants.

Investigations:

  • Fundus Photography: To document retinal findings.
  • Fluorescein Angiography: To assess capillary non-perfusion and leakage.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): To check for macular edema.

Management:

  • Glycemic Control: Strict blood sugar control to slow progression.
  • Ophthalmic Monitoring: Regular fundus examinations to monitor disease progression.
  • Laser Photocoagulation: In case of macular edema or risk of progression to PDR.
  • Intravitreal Injections: Anti-VEGF agents (e.g., ranibizumab) for diabetic macular edema.

Explanation of other options:

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) (Option D) is defined by neovascularization, which is explicitly absent in this case.

questions.text: A 46-year-old anxious man was brought to physician with complaints of insomnia, nightmares, fatigue, diminished libido, and blanching of the fingers when exposed to cold. The man, recently diagnosed with exertional angina, had been taking an anti-anginal drug for 1 month. Which of the following drug most likely caused the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, is used for exertional angina but can cause adverse effects due to β1 and β2 receptor blockade.
  • These include fatigue, insomnia, nightmares, diminished libido (via CNS effects), and Raynaud's phenomenon (blanching of fingers) due to unopposed α-mediated vasoconstriction from β2 blockade.
  • Propranolol is contraindicated in vasospastic angina due to its vasoconstrictive

Adverse effects of beta blockers (Mnemonic: BALD FISH)

  • Bronchoconstriction
  • Bradycardia
  • Arrhythmia
  • Lethargy
  • Disturbed glucose metabolism
  • Fatigue
  • Insomnia
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Hypotension

Explanations for other options:

Isosorbide mononitrate (Option B) causes vasodilation, leading to headaches, flushing, or hypotension, not CNS or vasoconstrictive symptoms.

Nitroglycerin (Option C), used for acute angina, causes headaches or hypotension, not insomnia, nightmares, or Raynaud’s phenomenon.

Nifedipine (Option D), a calcium channel blocker, causes vasodilation, leading to flushing, edema, or hypotension, not the described symptoms.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with severe itching, redness, and a mucopurulent discharge from his eyes, particularly worsening during the spring. On examination, he has large cobblestone-like papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and Horner-Trantas dots on the limbus. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of severe itching, redness, mucopurulent discharge, cobblestone-like papillae, and Horner-Trantas dots in spring suggest vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), a chronic allergic eye condition. Topical antihistamines (e.g., olopatadine, ketotifen) are the first-line treatment to relieve itching and redness by blocking histamine receptors.

Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC):

  • A chronic, allergic eye disease characterized by inflammation of the conjunctiva and cornea, typically occurring in the spring or early summer.
  • Signs for Limbal Type:
    • Horner Trantas spots: degenerated epithelial cells and eosinophils.
    • Pseudogerontoxon
  • Signs for palpebral type:
    • Giant papillae
  • Complications:
    • Shield ulcer
    • Limbal stem cells deficiency--> Corneal neovascularization
    • Developing Keratoconus
  • Etiology and Risk Factors:
    • Allergic Reaction: VKC is an allergic condition triggered by environmental allergens. The exact allergens can vary but include pollen, dust mites, and animal dander.
    • Age: Commonly affects children and young adults, particularly those with a history of atopy.
    • Climate: More prevalent in warm, dry climates.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms:
      • Itching: Severe itching is a hallmark symptom.
      • Redness: Conjunctival hyperemia and redness.
      • Discharge: Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge.
      • Photophobia: Sensitivity to light.
    • Signs:
      • Conjunctival Papillae: Large, cobblestone-like papillae, especially on the upper tarsal conjunctiva.
      • Corneal Changes: Horner-Trantas dots (whitish-gray, elevated lesions on the limbus) and potential corneal epithelial damage.
      • Eyelid Swelling: Swelling and thickening of the eyelids.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Allergy Testing:
      • Skin Prick Tests: To identify specific allergens.
      • Serum IgE Levels: Elevated in many cases of VKC.
  • Management:
    • Avoidance of Allergens:
      • Environmental Control: Minimizing exposure to known allergens, such as pollen.
    • Pharmacologic Treatment:
      • Topical Antihistamines: E.g., olopatadine or ketotifen.
      • Topical Mast Cell Stabilizers: E.g., cromolyn sodium.
      • Topical Corticosteroids: For severe inflammation, but used cautiously due to potential side effects.
      • Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs): E.g., ketorolac.
    • Surgical Intervention:
      • For Complications: Surgery may be required for significant corneal damage or to manage complications like severe scarring.

Explanation of other options:

Oral Corticosteroids: While effective, they are generally reserved for severe cases due to potential systemic side effects and are not typically used as first-line therapy.

Systemic Immunotherapy: Not usually the first approach for VKC. It is used in severe or refractory cases.

Topical Antibiotics: Not appropriate as the condition is allergic rather than bacterial, and antibiotics will not address the underlying allergic inflammation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a 15-year history of uncontrolled diabetes presents with gradually worsening vision in both eyes. On fundus examination, there is significant retinal thickening with hard exudates seen near the fovea. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows retinal thickening within 400 microns of the foveal center. Which of the following best describes the current condition?
questions.solution:
Retinal thickening and hard exudates near the fovea, with OCT confirming thickening within 400 microns of the foveal center, meet the ETDRS criteria for clinically significant macular edema (CSME).

Clinically significant macular edema (CSME):

  • Defined by the ETDRS criteria. The case mentions retinal thickening within 400 microns of the fovea, which meets one of the diagnostic criteria for CSME.

Clinically Significant Macular Edema (CSME):

  • Defined by ETDRS as:
    1. Retinal thickening at or within 500 microns of the foveal center.
    2. Hard exudates at or within 500 microns of the foveal center with adjacent thickening.
    3. Retinal thickening of at least 1 disc diameter within 1 disc diameter of the fovea.
  • Treatment: Anti-VEGF agents (e.g., Ranibizumab) are the first-line treatment for center-involving CSME. Focal/grid laser is also an option, particularly in non-center involving CSME.

Diabetic Macular Edema (DME):

  • It is a complication of diabetic retinopathy (DR) and refers to swelling of the macula caused by fluid accumulation due to leakage from retinal blood vessels. It is the most common cause of vision loss in patients with diabetic retinopathy.

Pathophysiology:

  1. Breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier:
    • Chronic hyperglycemia leads to capillary damage, endothelial dysfunction, and pericyte loss.
    • This results in increased vascular permeability, causing leakage of fluid and lipoprotein exudates into the macular region.
  2. Role of VEGF:
    • Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) is a key factor driving vascular leakage and neovascularization.
    • High levels of VEGF are associated with increased macular edema.

Risk Factors:

  • Poorly controlled diabetes: Long duration of diabetes and high HbA1c levels.
  • Hypertension and hyperlipidemia: Contributing to retinal vessel damage.
  • Pre-existing diabetic retinopathy: The more advanced the retinopathy, the higher the likelihood of DME.
  • Renal disease: Increases risk of macular edema due to fluid imbalance.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Painless, progressive blurring of central vision.
    • Visual distortion and difficulty reading.
    • Often bilateral but may be asymmetric.
  • Signs on Fundus Examination:
    • Retinal thickening and hard exudates in the macula.
    • Microaneurysms and hemorrhages in surrounding areas.
    • Cystoid spaces or subretinal fluid may be seen on OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography).

Investigations:

  1. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):
    • Provides cross-sectional imaging of the retina, showing retinal thickening, cystoid spaces, and fluid accumulation.
    • Helps in monitoring response to treatment.
  2. Fluorescein Angiography:
    • Used to evaluate the leakage from retinal vessels and the extent of macular ischemia.

Treatment Options:

  1. Anti-VEGF Therapy:
    • First-line treatment, especially for center-involving DME.
    • Agents such as Ranibizumab, Bevacizumab, and Aflibercept block VEGF and reduce fluid accumulation.
  2. Intravitreal Corticosteroids:
    • Used in patients unresponsive to anti-VEGF or in cases of inflammation.
    • Dexamethasone implant (Ozurdex) or triamcinolone can reduce macular swelling.
  3. Focal/Grid Laser Photocoagulation:
    • Used mainly for non-center-involving DME.
    • Aims to seal leaky microaneurysms and prevent further fluid leakage.
  4. Combination Therapy:
    • Anti-VEGF combined with focal/grid laser therapy is often more effective in reducing macular edema.

Prognosis:

  • Early treatment significantly improves visual outcomes.
  • Regular follow-ups and tight control of blood sugar, blood pressure, and lipid levels are critical to prevent recurrence or progression.

Explanation of other options:

Diffuse diabetic macular edema (Option A) involves widespread macular thickening but may not specifically involve the foveal center, unlike CSME.

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (Option C) encompasses early retinal changes (e.g., microaneurysms, hemorrhages) but does not specifically address macular edema.

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (Option D) involves neovascularization, which is not described in the findings.

questions.text: An 18 year old male patient was brought into the emergency department with a seizure that lasted 30 minutes without resolution. After securing airways & administering oxygen, which of the following pharmacologic agents is most appropriate to arrest the seizure?
questions.solution:
The patient has status epilepticus (seizure >5 minutes or recurrent seizures without recovery). Lorazepam, a short-acting benzodiazepine, is the first-line treatment due to its rapid onset (within minutes) and effectiveness in terminating seizures by enhancing GABA activity. It is given intravenously (2-4 mg, repeated every 10 minutes if needed) until seizure control.

BZD In Status Epilepticus :

  • Lorazepam
  • Diazepam
  • Midazolam

Explanation of other options:

Lidocaine (Option A) is a local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic used for ventricular arrhythmias, not seizures.

Chlordiazepoxide (Option C), a long-acting benzodiazepine, is used for anxiety or alcohol withdrawal, not acute seizure management, due to its slow onset.

Triazolam (Option D), a short-acting benzodiazepine, is used for insomnia, not acute seizure termination, due to its oral administration and slower action.

Key Takeaway :

A short-acting benzodiazepine such as lorazepam is usually the best choice in the acute setting to arrest status epilepticus.

choices.text: Immediate fitting of contact lenses or glasses to correct the refractive error
Strict adherence to amblyopia treatment protocols, including patching of the non-affected eye
Regular monitoring for secondary cataract development and timely YAG laser capsulotomy if necessary
Early initiation of strabismus surgery to prevent ocular misalignment

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is diagnosed with a unilateral congenital cataract. You plan to perform cataract surgery. Which of the following is the most critical postoperative intervention to ensure optimal visual development?
questions.solution:
Congenital cataracts require early surgery (within months of birth) to prevent amblyopia, where the brain suppresses vision in the affected eye due to a lack of visual stimulation. Post-surgery, strict amblyopia treatment (e.g., patching the non-affected eye) is critical to stimulate visual development in the operated eye, promoting neural plasticity and preventing permanent vision loss.

Congenital Cataract:

Clinical Presentation:

  • Infant Cataracts: Often detected by parental observation of a white reflex (leukocoria) or during routine newborn screening.
  • Older Children: May present with decreased vision, strabismus, or amblyopia.

Diagnostic Tests:

  • Slit Lamp Examination:To assess the cataract's location and density.
  • Retinal Examination:To check for associated abnormalities.
  • Ultrasonography: Useful for detailed assessment of the cataract and associated conditions, particularly if the view is obscured.

Management:

Surgical Intervention:

  • Timing:
    • Infant Cataracts: Early intervention is crucial to prevent amblyopia and promote normal visual development. Surgery is typically performed within the first few months of life.
  • Technique:
    • Phacoemulsification: The preferred method for children over 2 years of age.
    • usually Lens aspiration is enough as the cataract is soft
    • They will need a posterior capsulorhexis

Postoperative Care:

  • Visual Rehabilitation:
    • Amblyopia Treatment: Includes patching of the non-affected eye to stimulate the amblyopic eye, along with corrective lenses.
    • Glasses or Contact Lenses: Typically required to correct refractive errors post-surgery.
  • Follow-up:
    • Regular Check-ups: To monitor for complications such as glaucoma, secondary cataract (posterior capsule opacification), and ensure proper visual development.
    • Additional Surgeries: May be required for secondary cataract or other complications.

Complications:

  • Postoperative Glaucoma: Regular monitoring is essential.
  • Posterior Capsule Opacification: Can be treated with a YAG laser capsulotomy.
  • Strabismus: May require additional management if present.

Explanation of other options:

Immediate fitting of contact lenses or glasses (Option A): Corrective lenses address refractive errors but are insufficient alone to prevent amblyopia, which requires active visual stimulation.

Regular monitoring for secondary cataract (Option C): Monitoring for posterior capsule opacification is important, but not the primary intervention for visual development.

Early initiation of strabismus surgery (Option D): Strabismus surgery may be needed if misalignment develops, but it is not the immediate priority post-cataract surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is remnant of green coloured structure?
questions.solution:
The arrow marked structure is Allantois.

Allantois:

  • It is small diverticulum that arises from caudal wall of the yolk sac on day 16 and extends into connecting stalk.
  • After folding of embryo, the allantois is connected with dilated terminal part of hindgut called cloaca.

Function:

  1. It is vascularised by Allantoic vessels that later become fetal umbilical arteries and veins.
  2. It is represented by median umbilical ligament in adults.
  3. It also contributes a bit to formation of urinary bladder.

Explanation of other options:

Medial umbilical ligament (Option B): The medial umbilical ligament is a remnant of the umbilical arteries, not the allantois.

Meckel's diverticulum (Option C) is a remnant of the vitellointestinal duct, not the allantois.

Ligamentum teres hepatis (Option D): The ligamentum teres hepatis is a remnant of the left umbilical vein, not the allantois.

questions.text: The device shown in the picture below is used in which of the following condition ?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the picture given above is called Grommet.

  • A grommet (tympanostomy tube) is used in serous otitis media (SOM), or otitis media with effusion, to restore middle ear ventilation and drain fluid.
  • SOM involves fluid accumulation without acute infection, often requiring myringotomy with grommet insertion, especially in children with persistent effusion. Underlying causes (e.g., adenoid hypertrophy) may also require treatment.

Explanation of other options:

ASOM (Option A): Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) is managed with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs, not grommets, as it is an acute infection.

Safe CSOM (Option B): Safe chronic suppurative otitis media involves chronic perforation and is treated with tympanoplasty, not grommets.

Unsafe CSOM (Option D): Unsafe CSOM requires mastoidectomy due to cholesteatoma or bone erosion, not grommet insertion.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient with a history of mild hepatic impairment brought to the medicine department with seizure disorder. His physician has prescribed oxcarbazepine instead of carbamazepine. Which of the following adverse effects is more with oxcarbazepine as compared to carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
• Oxcarbazepine is preferred over carbamazepine in patients with mild hepatic impairment due to its lower hepatotoxicity risk.
  • However, oxcarbazepine has a higher incidence of dilutional hyponatremia, caused by increased antidiuretic hormone activity, leading to water retention.
  • Serum sodium levels should be monitored, especially in the first few months.
  • Other side effects like drowsiness, ataxia, and rash are less frequent than with carbamazepine.

Explanations for other options:

Thrombocytopenia (Option A) is more common with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, which has a lower risk of hematologic side effects.

Rash (Option C) is more frequent with carbamazepine due to its higher potential for hypersensitivity reactions, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

Hepatotoxicity (Option D) is more associated with carbamazepine, making oxcarbazepine safer in hepatic impairment.

Key Takeaway:

The risk of Dilutional hyponatremia is higher with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine

questions.text: The Basilar membrane in the inner ear separates which of the two structures?
questions.solution:
The basilar membrane forms the base of the scala media (cochlear duct) in the cochlea, separating it from the scala tympani. It supports the organ of Corti, which contains hair cells for sound transduction.

Scala media:

  • It is a coiled tube, coiling over a bony axis, which is known as the It takes 2 and ½ to 2 and ¾ turns around the modiolus.
  • The Scala media is triangular in cross-section and is bounded by:
    • Basilar membrane: it separates Scala media from Scala tympani. The organ of Corti rests on the Basilar membrane.
    • Reissner membrane: it separates Scala media from Scala vestibuli.
    • Striae vascularis: It is the site of production of endolymph. It plays an important role in cochlear homeostasis by generating the endocochlear potential.

Explanation of other options:

Scala vestibuli and scala media (Option B): These are separated by Reissner's membrane, not the basilar membrane.

Scala tympani and scala vestibuli (Option C): These are separated by the entire scala media, not directly by the basilar membrane.

Scala media and stria vascularis (Option D): The stria vascularis is part of the scala media's lateral wall, not separated by the basilar membrane.

questions.text: Impedance audiometry is an objective test used for assessment of middle ear. What is the frequency of the probe used in impedance audiometry?
questions.solution:
Impedance audiometry, including tympanometry, assesses middle ear function by measuring resistance to sound energy flow. A 226 Hz probe tone is standard for adults, as it effectively evaluates tympanic membrane mobility under varying external auditory canal pressures (+220 to -400 mmHg). In infants, a 1000 Hz probe is used due to differences in ear canal compliance.

The Tympanometry probe has 3 channels:

  • Through one channel, a sound of 226hz or 220hz is delivered to TM. In infants and neonates, a high-frequency probe of 1000hz is used.
  • Whenever a sound strikes the TM, some of it gets absorbed and some of it gets reflected. The 2nd channel picks up the reflected sound.
  • The 3rd channel changes the pressure of EAC from +220 to -400. When the pressure of the EAC and the middle ear becomes equal, maximum mobility of the TM happens.

questions.text: A 34 year old patient visits an otolaryngologist with complaints of recurrent sinusitis. The surgeon decides to perform sinus surgery to debride the scarred sinus tissue. During the procedure, the surgeon elects to use an agent that has good local anesthesia as well as vasoconstrictive properties. Which of the following agents is most suitable surgeon has used?
questions.solution:
• Cocaine is a unique local anesthetic with intrinsic vasoconstrictive properties due to norepinephrine reuptake inhibition, making it ideal for sinus surgery to reduce bleeding and provide topical anesthesia.
  • Unlike other local anesthetics, it does not require epinephrine.
  • Cocaine is metabolized in the liver, not by pseudocholinesterase, and should not be administered intravenously or with adrenaline due to sympathomimetic effects (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension).

Explanation of other options:

Procaine (Option B), an ester-type anesthetic, lacks vasoconstrictive properties and is not topically active, making it unsuitable for sinus surgery.

Tetracaine (Option C) is used for spinal or ophthalmic anesthesia but lacks vasoconstrictive properties and is not ideal for sinus surgery.

Lidocaine (Option D), an amide anesthetic, is a vasodilator and requires epinephrine for vasoconstriction, unlike cocaine's intrinsic effect.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cocaine has topical LA activity & has intrinsic vasoconstrictive activity that aids in hemostasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with complaints of Hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, the red reflex sign was seen on the Tympanic membrane. Pneumatic otoscopy examination showed the brown's sign was positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulsatile tinnitus, a red reflex sign (vascular mass behind the tympanic membrane), and positive Brown's sign (blanching of the tumor on pneumatic otoscopy) are characteristic of a glomus tumor (glomus tympanicum or jugulare).

Glomus Tumor:

Origin: Paraganglioma (Usually non chromaffin) :

  • Tympanic plexus : Glomus tympanicum (M/c)
  • Jugular bulb (CN 9, 10, 11) : Glomus jugulare

C/F :

  • Pulsatile tinnitus + CHL.
  • Aquino sign (Glomus jugulare): Blanching of the Tumor on carotid compression.
  • Brown's sign/pulsation sign:On siegelization.

Investigation:

  • CECT(Best) → Phelp's sign: Erosion of crest of bone b/w ICA & jugular bulb.
  • Preop Ix: Urinary VMA ↑ as 10% tumors are multicentric.

Mx :

  • Slow-growing tumors → Observation.
  • Small tumors → Stereotactic radiosurgery.
  • Surgical excision.

Note: Classification of jugulotympanic paragangliomas: Fisch classification.

Glomus tumor in the middle ear:

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A) presents as an ulceroproliferative lesion, not with pulsatile tinnitus or vascular signs.

Osteoma (Option B) is a benign bony growth in the external auditory canal, not associated with pulsatile tinnitus or tympanic membrane signs.

Acoustic neuroma (Option C) (vestibular schwannoma) causes sensorineural hearing loss, not pulsatile tinnitus or tympanic membrane signs.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female came to the medicine OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. She was prescribed different medicines to curb the symptoms, following which she came back with a maculopapular rash over arms & legs as given in the image below. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Amoxicillin, a penicillin antibiotic commonly prescribed for respiratory infections, is associated with hypersensitivity reactions, including maculopapular rashes, in 1-4% of patients, particularly those with an allergic diathesis.

Adverse effects of Penicillins:

  • Penicillin G is one of the most nontoxic antibiotics; up to 20 MU has been injected in a day without any organ toxicity.

Local irritancy and direct toxicity

  • Pain at i.m. Injection site,
  • Nausea on oral ingestion and
  • Thrombophlebitis of an injected vein are dose-related expressions of irritancy.
  • Accidental i.v. injection of procaine penicillin produces CNS stimulation, hallucinations and convulsions due to procaine.

Hypersensitivity:

  • Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin reactions. Frequent manifestations of penicillin allergy are:
    • Rash,
    • Itching,
    • Urticaria
    • Fever.
  • Wheezing, angioneurotic edema, serum sickness and exfoliative dermatitis are less common.
  • Anaphylaxis is rare (1 to 4 per 10,000 patients), but may be fatal.

Adverse Effects of Penicillins

Explanation of other options:

Fexofenadine (Option A), an antihistamine, treats allergic reactions and is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash.

Salbutamol (Option B), a beta-agonist for asthma, may cause tremors or tachycardia but not rashes.

Corticosteroids (Option D) manage allergic reactions and do not typically cause maculopapular rashes.

Key Takeaway:

  • Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin Hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child presented with bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss. Her parents were advised that the patient needs to undergo cochlear implantation. Which of the following structures is required to be intact for successful cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Cochlear implants bypass defective outer and inner hair cells by directly stimulating the auditory nerve, which must be intact for successful hearing restoration. They are indicated for bilateral severe-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss unresponsive to hearing aids, ideally implanted by age 1. Contraindications include auditory nerve aplasia (e.g., Michel aplasia).

Cochlear implant :

  • Replaces the organ of Corti: Stimulates the auditory nerve.
  • Indication: B/L severe to profound HL (No benefit by hearing aid trial).
  • Insertion: Mastoid → Facial recess → Middle ear → Round window →Scala tympani (Inner ear).
  • C/I: Michel aplasia, central auditory lesions.
  • It should be implanted as early as 1 year of age.

Explanation of other options:

Outer hair cells (Option A) are dysfunctional in sensorineural hearing loss, and cochlear implants bypass them.

Inner hair cells (Option B) are also bypassed by cochlear implants, which stimulate the auditory nerve directly.

All of the above (Option D): Only the auditory nerve's integrity is required, not the hair cells.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient with a history of borderline leprosy was receiving multidrug therapy (MDT). Later he developed skin lesions and presented to dermatologist with features shown in the figure below. What should be the treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions during MDT for borderline leprosy suggest erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), a Jarisch-Herxheimer-type reaction due to antigen release. MDT should continue to treat leprosy, while prednisolone (40-60 mg/day, tapered over 2-3 months) controls severe ENL.

Reactions in leprosy:

Lepra reaction

  • This occurs in LL, usually coincides with the institution of chemotherapy and/or intercurrent infection.
  • It is a Jarish Herxheimer (Arthus) type of reaction due to the release of antigens from the killed bacilli, and may be mild, severe, or life-threatening, i.e,. erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL).
  • Temporary discontinuation of dapsone is recommended only in severe cases.
  • Clofazimine (200 mg daily) is effective in controlling the reaction (except the severe one), probably because of its antiinflammatory property.
  • For severe reactions, prednisolone 40-60 mg/day is started immediately and continued till the reaction subsides. The dose is then tapered over 2-3 months

Reversal reaction

  • This is seen in TT and BL cases, and is a manifestation of delayed hypersensitivity to M. leprae antigens.
  • Cutaneous ulceration, multiple nerve involvement with swollen, painful and tender nerves occur suddenly even after completion of therapy.
  • Reversal reaction is treated with clofazimine or corticosteroids in the same way as ENL, but thalidomide is ineffective.

Explanation of other options:

Stop MDT and give thalidomide (Option A): Stopping MDT is incorrect, as leprosy treatment must continue; thalidomide is not first-line.

Continue MDT and give thalidomide (Option B): While MDT should continue, thalidomide is not the preferred treatment for ENL; steroids are first-line.

Stop MDT and give steroids (Option C): Stopping MDT is incorrect, as leprosy treatment must persist during reactions.

choices.text: The mucosa appears pale and there is bleeding on removal of crusting
Alkaline nasal douching is given containing Sodium chloride, Sodium bicarbonate, Sodium biurate and Glucose
Kimicetine solution containing Chloramphenicol, propylene glycol, estradiol and vitamin D2 is used

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient presented with complaints of nasal discharge and nasal obstruction. On examination nose was found to be filled with crusting and the nasal cavity was found to be roomy. The discharge was foul smelling. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
The symptoms suggest atrophic rhinitis, characterized by mucosal atrophy, crusting, and foul-smelling discharge. Management includes alkaline nasal douching with sodium chloride, sodium bicarbonate, and sodium borate (not glucose) to loosen crusts, and Kimicetine solution (chloramphenicol, propylene glycol, estradiol, vitamin D2) for local treatment.

Atrophic Rhinitis:

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction develops despite roomy nasal cavities mainly due to excessive crusting and loss of nerve supply due to atrophy.
  • Foul-smelling nasal discharge, but the irony here is patient is not able to smell the nasal discharge due to atrophy of the nerve, hence it is called merciful anosmia.

Management :

Medical :

  • Alkaline douching containing Sodium chloride, Sodium bicarbonate, Sodium biurate. Glucose is not present in the Alkaline douching.
  • Kimicetine solution containing Chloramphenicol, propylene glycol, estradiol and vitamin D2 is used.
  • Oestrogen spray.

Surgical management :

  • Young's operation and Lautenslager's operation, in which the nasal cavity is partially or completely closed temporarily.

Explanation of other options:

Lautenslager's operation is useful (Option A): This is true; Lautenslager's operation reduces crusting by partially closing the nasal cavity.

The mucosa appears pale, and there is bleeding on removal of crusting (Option B): This is true; atrophic rhinitis features pale, atrophied mucosa with bleeding upon crust removal.

Kimicetine solution contains chloramphenicol, propylene glycol, estradiol, and vitamin D2 (Option D): This is true; Kimicetine solution manages infections and promotes mucosal health.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman who underwent hip replacement was discharged from the hospital with an appropriate post-discharge therapy that included daily subcutaneous injection of regular heparin. Which of the following laboratory examinations should be performed frequently during the heparin treatment?
questions.solution:
• Heparin can cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) in up to 5% of patients, a serious condition involving antibody-mediated platelet destruction and thrombosis risk.
  • Weekly platelet count monitoring is essential to detect HIT early.
  • Heparin's anticoagulant effect is monitored with aPTT, not bleeding time.

Side Effects of Heparin:

  • Alopecia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hyperkalemia: It inhibits aldosterone synthesis.
  • Activates lipoprotein lipase: reduces triglyceride levels.
  • Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT)

Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT):

  • It is the most dangerous side effect of heparin.
  • Leads to Increased risk of thrombosis: venous (DVT/PE) > arterial (MI/Stroke)
  • Definitive diagnosis: Serotonin assay (released by destroyed platelets)
  • Treatment: Stop heparin (HMW>LMW)
    • Start direct thrombin inhibitors parenteral, like Argatroban > Lepirudin (drug of choice)
    • Fondaparinux (synthetic ULMW heparin) by injection
    • Danaparoid (oral synthetic heparin)
    • No role of platelet transfusion (antibodies are already present against platelets)

Explanation of other options:

Red blood cell count (RBC) (Option A): Heparin does not directly affect RBC counts, making this monitoring unnecessary.

Plasma K+ level (Option C): Heparin can cause hyperkalemia, but routine monitoring is not required unless clinically suspected.

Bleeding time (Option D) is not used to monitor heparin; aPTT is the standard test for anticoagulant effect.

Key Takeaway:

  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a serious adverse effect of heparin; a platelet count should be performed weekly during heparin treatment.

choices.text: Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong
Start ART after the First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after the First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

questions.text: A pregnant lady was found to be HIV positive in the First trimester. The next line of management is:
questions.solution:
• Antiretroviral therapy (ART)should be initiated immediately in all HIV-positive pregnant women, regardless of the trimester. Early initiation of ART helps reduce maternal viral load, preventing mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV.
  • Triple Drug Therapy: The standard regimen typically involves a combination of three antiretroviral drugs from at least two classes. Common regimens include:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine/Emtricitabine + Efavirenz (or other integrase inhibitors like Dolutegravir).

  • Current guidelines recommend that ART should be continued lifelong in HIV-positive women to maintain viral suppression and prevent further transmission to the child and others.

Explanation of other options:

Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery (Option A): Stopping ART post-delivery is incorrect; lifelong therapy is required for sustained viral suppression.

Start ART after the first trimester, continue throughout pregnancy, and till 6 weeks after delivery (Option C): Delaying ART increases MTCT risk, and stopping post-delivery is not recommended.

Start ART after the first trimester, continue throughout pregnancy, and till lifelong (Option D): Delaying ART is incorrect, as immediate initiation minimizes transmission risk.

Key Takeaways:

ART is started as soon as the diagnosis is made and continued lifelong.

Reference: https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_HIV_Care_and_Treatment_2021.pdf

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department by his wife with symptoms of sudden difficulty breathing, sweating and anxiety. On history taking he was spraying insecticide when this happened. The patient is emergently intubated and given atropine. Which of the following medications should be added along with atropine?
questions.solution:
The symptoms suggest organophosphate poisoning, a cholinesterase inhibitor causing muscarinic (e.g., bronchospasm, sweating) and nicotinic (e.g., paralysis) effects. Atropine counteracts muscarinic symptoms. Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator, is essential within hours of exposure to reverse neuromuscular paralysis by regenerating acetylcholinesterase before enzyme ageing.

Anticholinesterase Poisoning:

Clinical features:

Treatment

  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison-fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, and gastric lavage according to need.
  2. Maintain a patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures-maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes:

(a) Atropine:

  • It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonise the central effects.
  • It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis, which is a nicotinic action.
  • All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. Repeated every 10 minutes till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear

(b) Cholinesterase reactivators:

  • Oximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in the case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.
  • Pralidoxime is ineffective as an antidote to carbamate anti-ChEs (physostigmine, neostigmine, carbaryl, propoxur)
  • Treatment should be started as early as possible(within a few hours), before the phosphorylated enzyme has undergone 'ageing' and become resistant to hydrolysis.
  • Other oximes are
  1. Obidoxime --> more potent than pralidoxime
  2. Diacetyl-monoxime (DAM) - lipophilic.

Explanation of other options:

Physostigmine (Option A), a cholinesterase inhibitor, worsens organophosphate poisoning and is used for anticholinergic overdose.

Propranolol (Option B), a beta-blocker, is irrelevant and may exacerbate bronchospasm in organophosphate poisoning.

Phenylephrine (Option D), an alpha-agonist, is used for hypotension but does not address cholinesterase inhibition.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pralidoxime and diacetyl monoxime are cholinesterase regenerator compounds used for organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: Interval between Primary case and secondary case is known as
questions.solution: The serial interval is the time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and a secondary case infected by the primary case. It is used in epidemiology to estimate incubation periods and transmission dynamics of infectious diseases.

questions.text: DNA hybridization, where DNA is detected using specific probes, is called:
questions.solution:
Southern blotting detects specific DNA sequences via hybridization with labeled probes. It involves DNA digestion, gel electrophoresis, membrane transfer, and probing with complementary DNA.

Applications of Southern Blotting:

  • Genetic Testing: To detect specific mutations related to genetic diseases.
  • Forensic Analysis: In criminal investigations, to match DNA samples.
  • Gene Cloning: To confirm the presence of specific gene sequences in recombinant DNA studies.

Explanation of other options:

Northern blot (Option B): Northern blotting detects RNA sequences, not DNA, using similar hybridisation principles.

Eastern blot (Option C): Eastern blotting detects glycoproteins, focusing on post-translational modifications, not nucleic acids.

Western blot (Option D): Western blotting detects proteins using antibodies, not DNA hybridisation.

Key Takeaways:

The Southern blot technique is used for DNA hybridization to detect specific DNA sequences using labelled probes.

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency will be responsible for Keshan's Disease?
questions.solution:
• Keshan's Disease is a dilated cardiomyopathy closely related to a diet deficient in the mineral Selenium.
  • Cardiomyopathy with myocardial necrosis results from a combination of selenium deficiency from poor dietary intake and secondary viral infection. It is named for the northeastern Chinese country Keshan, where the disease prevalence is high because of selenium-deficient soil.

Key Takeaways:

Keshan's Disease is a dilated cardiomyopathy closely related with a diet deficient in the mineral Selenium.

choices.text: It has a cyst stage with a single nucleus.
The trophozoite form is larger than that of Entamoeba histolytica.
It causes severe gastrointestinal disease in humans.
The cystic form lacks a prominent glycogen mass.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Entamoeba coli?
questions.solution:
• Entamoeba coli trophozoites are significantly larger, measuring 20-50 µm in diameter, which distinguishes them from the smaller E. histolytica.
  • The cyst stage of E. coli features multiple nuclei (up to eight), which aids in identification and classification; thus, option A is incorrect.
  • E. coli is a non-pathogenic commensal, meaning it typically resides in the intestines without causing disease, contradicting option C.
  • The cystic form of E. coli indeed contains a prominent glycogen mass, particularly during the early stages.

Explanation of other options:

It has a cyst stage with a single nucleus (Option A): E. coli cysts typically have multiple nuclei (up to eight), unlike E. histolytica, which may have one to four.

It causes severe gastrointestinal disease (Option C): E. coli is non-pathogenic and does not cause gastrointestinal disease, unlike E. histolytica.

The cystic form lacks a prominent glycogen mass (Option D): E. coli cysts have a prominent glycogen mass, especially in early stages.

Key Takeaway:

Entamoeba coli is a larger, non-pathogenic intestinal amoeba with unique features in its cyst and trophozoite forms, especially in comparison to Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.text: The amount of sewage flowing in a system in 24 hours is called:
questions.solution:
Dry weather flow is the average amount of sewage flowing through a sewerage system over 24 hours, excluding stormwater.

  • Sewage: Is waste water from a community, containing solid and liquid excreta, derived from houses, street and yard washings, factories and industries
  • Composition of sewage: 99.9% water + 0.1% solids (organic & inorganic)
  • The strength of sewage is expressed in terms of:
    • Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD):Is defined as the 'amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage' during a specified period (Generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20° C) for aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living organisms
      • BOD is the most important test done on sewage (done through the Dilution method and Manometric method)
      • Strong Sewage has BOD > 300 g/liter and Weak Sewage has BOD < 100 g/liter
    • Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD):Measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of organic matter in a sample, which is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidiser. Potassium dichromate is best for COD estimation.
    • Suspended solids: The amount in domestic sewage varies from 100 - 500 mg/litre
    • Strong Sewage has suspended solids amount > 500 mg/litre, and Weak Sewage has suspended solids amount < 100 mg/litre.

Explanation of other options:

Sewage rate (Option A): This is not a standard term; it may confuse with flow rate but is not specific to 24-hour flow.

RCA index (Option C) is not related to sewage flow and is not a recognized term in this context.

Sludge (Option D) is the solid residue from sewage treatment, not the liquid flow in the system.

Key Takeaways:

Dry weather flow: Is the average amount of sewage that flows in the sewerage system in 24 hours

questions.text: Which species of hookworm is most commonly associated with cutaneous larva migrans?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is caused by Ancylostoma braziliense larvae, which penetrate the skin and migrate in the epidermis, causing itchy, serpiginous tracks.

  • Ancylostoma brazilienseis the most common species associated with cutaneous larva migrans (CLM), which occurs when hookworm larvae penetrate the skin and migrate through the epidermis, causing visible, itchy tracks.
  • The condition is primarily seen in individuals who come into contact with contaminated soil, especially in warm, coastal regions where the larvae are prevalent.
  • CLM is characterised by serpiginous(snake-like) lesions, and while it can cause discomfort, it typically does not lead to severe systemic illness.
  • In contrast, Ancylostoma duodenaleand Necator americanus are well-known for causing hookworm disease, leading to symptoms such as anaemia, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea, as they attach to the intestinal lining and feed on blood.
  • Strongyloides stercoralisis a different type of parasitic worm that may cause skin symptoms upon penetration but does not lead to the distinct serpentine lesions associated with CLM.

Explanation of other options:

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option A) causes intestinal hookworm disease with anaemia, not CLM.

Necator americanus (Option B) also causes intestinal hookworm infection, not cutaneous lesions.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option C) causes larva currens, not the serpiginous tracks of CLM, and is not a hookworm.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ancylostoma brazilienseis the primary species linked to cutaneous larva migrans, marked by larvae migrating under the skin, producing itchy, serpentine tracks, while other hookworm species primarily cause intestinal issues.

The All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) New Delhi was established with financial assistance from New Zealand under the Colombo Plan, which was an initiative aimed at promoting economic and social development in Asia and the Pacific region.

questions.text: The vector for Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is:
questions.solution:
Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a viral disease transmitted by ticks, primarily of the Hyalomma genus, which act as vectors between animals and humans. Human-to-human transmission can occur via bodily fluids. The disease causes fever, haemorrhage, and high mortality in severe cases.

Key Takeaways:

The vector for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is a tick, specifically from the Hyalomma genus. These ticks transmit the virus to humans and animals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a productive cough with profuse expectoration. He also reports dyspnoea on exertion, which is an insidious onset, gradually progressive. X-ray shows a tram track sign. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis:

  • Definition: An irreversible airway dilation, which can be focal or diffuse.
  • Types: The most common form is cylindrical or tubular bronchiectasis.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Persistent productive cough: Characterised by the production of thick, tenacious sputum.
    • Dyspnea on exertion: Gradually progressive, indicating worsening respiratory function.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • X-ray: May show tram track sign, which indicates parallel linear opacities due to bronchial wall thickening, but is less sensitive.
    • HRCT Chest: The imaging modality of choice, showing:
      • Airway dilation(tram tracks or signet-ring sign)
      • Lack of bronchial tapering
      • Bronchial wall thickening
      • Inspissated secretions(tree-in-bud pattern)

Explanation of other options:

Chronic bronchitis (Option A) involves chronic cough and sputum but lacks the tram track sign or airway dilation.

Emphysema (Option C) causes alveolar destruction and hyperinflation, not the tram track sign or productive cough.

Both A and B (Option D): The tram track sign specifically points to bronchiectasis, not chronic bronchitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bronchiectasis is characterized by irreversible airway dilation and significant sputum production.
  • X-ray findings such as the tram track sign, alongside clinical symptoms, strongly support the diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the key distinguishing feature between TTP and HUS?
questions.solution:
• Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterised by severe ADAMTS13 enzyme deficiency (<10%), leading to microvascular thrombosis from ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers.
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) typically has normal ADAMTS13 activity and is often linked to Shiga toxin or complement dysregulation.
  • Both feature microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia, but TTP has prominent neurological symptoms, while HUS has more severe renal failure.

Explanation of other options:

Presence of schistocytes (Option A): Schistocytes are present in both TTP and HUS due to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

Severity of renal failure (Option B): While HUS often has more severe renal failure, this is not a definitive distinguishing feature.

Presence of neurological symptoms (Option C): Neurological symptoms are more common in TTP but can occur in HUS, making this less reliable.

Key Takeaways:

TTP is characterized by a deficiency in ADAMTS13 enzyme activity, which leads to the accumulation of ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers and subsequent microvascular thrombosis.

choices.text: Reduced diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide

questions.text: Which of the following patterns of pulmonary function test confirms the diagnosis of obstructive lung disease?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lung diseases (e.g., asthma, COPD) are confirmed by a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%), indicating airflow limitation.

Obstructive Lung Disease:

  • Primarily caused by airway diseases, affecting airflow.
  • Key PFT Indicator:
    • FEV1/FVC <70%is the hallmark for confirming obstructive lung disease.
  • Comparison of Lung Function Tests:
    • FEV1/FVC Ratio:
      • Obstructive:<70% (indicates significant obstruction).
      • Restrictive:>70% (airflow is preserved despite reduced lung volumes).
  • Diffusion Capacity (DLCO):
    • Normalin asthma; may be decreased in COPD due to parenchymal involvement.
  • Total Lung Capacity (TLC):
    • Usually normalin obstructive lung disease, may be decreased in restrictive lung diseases.

Explanation of other options:

Total lung capacity <80% (Option A): Reduced TLC is characteristic of restrictive lung disease, not obstructive disease.

Reduced diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (Option C): Reduced DLCO may occur in COPD, but is not specific to obstructive disease.

All of the above (Option D): Only FEV1/FVC <70% is definitive for obstructive lung disease.

Key Takeaways:

A FEV1/FVC ratio <70%is essential for diagnosing obstructive lung disease.

choices.text: <1.0 cm²/m² of body surface area
<1.50 cm²/m² of body surface area

questions.text: In adults Severe aortic stenosis is defined as aortic valve area of?
questions.solution:
• Severe Aortic Stenosis (AS):
    • Defined by a valve area <1.0 cm² .
    • Moderate AS: valve area 1.0-1.5 cm² .
    • Mild AS: valve area 1.5-2.0 cm² .
  • Aortic Valve Sclerosis:
    • Associated with a jet velocity of <2.5 m/s.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Doppler echocardiography is essential for estimating valve gradient and area.
    • A high transvalvular gradient often indicates severe obstruction.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Pulsus parvus et tardus:
      • Characterised by a slow-rising carotid pulse with a delayed peak.
    • Auscultation:
      • A systolic ejection murmur: low-pitched, rough, loudest at the second right intercostal space.
      • Murmur often transmitted to the carotids may be confused with mitral regurgitation (Gallavardin effect).
    • Symptoms of Severe AS:
      • Cardinal Symptoms:
        • Exertional dyspnoea: Difficulty breathing during activity.
        • Angina pectoris: Chest pain due to reduced coronary perfusion.
        • Syncope: Dizziness or fainting from reduced cardiac output.
      • Impairment of Left Ventricular (LV) Function
        • LV dilation and reduced systolic function may occur as AS progresses.
        • Patients may present with a low-flow, low-gradient severe AS even with a normal ejection fraction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Severe aortic stenosis is critically defined by a valve area <1.0 cm².
  • Recognising the severity is essential for timely intervention, particularly regarding valve replacement, to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in Acute Nephritic syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Proteinuria >3.0 g/day is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome, which also features hypoalbuminemia and oedema.

  • Acute Nephritic Syndrome is associated with:
    • Haematuria with RBC casts, indicating glomerular damage.
    • Proteinuria: Typically mild (1-2 g/day), reflecting mild glomerular leakage.
    • Hypertension, due to fluid retention and impaired kidney function.
    • Rising serum creatinine, reflecting reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • >3.0 grams/day proteinuria is excessive for nephritic syndrome and is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome also features hypoalbuminemia and severe oedema.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nephritic Syndrome: Mild proteinuria (<3 g/day), haematuria, hypertension, and rising creatinine.
  • Nephrotic Syndrome: Marked by >3 g/day proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and significant oedema.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of swelling in the right jaw, weight loss, fever, and night sweats.

Physical examination reveals:
1. Palpable lymphadenopathy in the neck and axilla
2. Hepatosplenomegaly

Biopsy of the mass reveals: 'Starry sky' appearance.

Which of the following chromosomal translocations is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The "starry sky" biopsy appearance and clinical features are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. The t(8;14)(q24;q32) translocation, involving the MYC oncogene and IGH gene, is seen in ~80% of cases, driving rapid tumor proliferation.

  • Biopsy findings of a starry sky appearance are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • t(8;14) translocation is a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • The t(8;14)(q24;q32) translocation involves the MYC oncogene on chromosome 8 and the IGH gene on chromosome 14, leading to overexpression of MYC protein.
  • This translocation is seen in approximately 80% of Burkitt lymphoma cases.

Explanation of other options:

t(11;14)(q13;q32) (Option B) is associated with mantle cell lymphoma, not Burkitt lymphoma.

t(14;18)(q32;q21) (Option C) is characteristic of follicular lymphoma, involving BCL2 overexpression.

t(4;11)(q21;q23) (Option D) is linked to acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, not Burkitt lymphoma.

Key Takeaways:

t(8;14) translocation is a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma

choices.text: Correlates with a genetic mutation affecting copper metabolism
Associated with an autoimmune response, causing inflammatory deposits
Accompanied by systemic symptoms of vitamin A deficiency
Indicates a systemic calcium metabolism disorder

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient with recent onset of hepatic dysfunction and psychiatric symptoms presents with a unique corneal finding. On examination, a ring is noted at the corneal margin. Which of the following factors most accurately differentiates this finding from similar corneal deposits seen in other systemic conditions?
questions.solution:
• The image shows the KF ring.
  • The Kayser-Fleischer ring is associated with Wilson's disease, which is caused by a genetic mutation affecting copper metabolism (ATP7B gene).
  • The greenish-brown hue is characteristic of copper deposition, not calcium.
  • Iron and calcium deposits result from different conditions
  • Autoimmune conditions may cause different types of corneal deposits, but are not related to the Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • Genetic Basis: Wilson's disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and involves mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase.
  • Diagnostic Testing: Diagnostic tests include serum ceruloplasmin levels (typically low in Wilson's disease), 24-hour urinary copper excretion (often elevated), and liver biopsy for copper content.
  • Treatment: Management involves chelating agents (e.g., D-penicillamine) to promote copper excretion, zinc therapy to reduce copper absorption, and dietary modifications.

Explanation of other options:

Associated with an autoimmune response causing inflammatory deposits (Option B): Autoimmune conditions (e.g., uveitis) may cause corneal precipitates, but these are not Kayser-Fleischer rings.

Accompanied by systemic symptoms of vitamin A deficiency (Option C): Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia and night blindness, not corneal rings.

Indicates a systemic calcium metabolism disorder (Option D): Calcium deposits (e.g., band keratopathy) are associated with hyperparathyroidism, not copper metabolism.

questions.text: What will be the stage of chronic kidney disease of a patient with eGFR of 40 ml/min and persistent proteinuria of >300 mg/g?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is staged using eGFR (G1-G5) and albuminuria (A1-A3). An eGFR of 40 ml/min corresponds to stage G3b (30-44 ml/min), and proteinuria >300 mg/g indicates A3 (high proteinuria). Thus, the stage is G3bA3.

  • Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Staging:
    • Stage Classification:CKD is classified based on glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and the degree of proteinuria.

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient's CKD stage is G3bA3 due to eGFR of 40 ml/min and high proteinuria

choices.text: Tattoo or piercing within the last 12 months

questions.text: Which of the following would result in a permanent deferral of a blood donor?
questions.solution:
HIV or hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection results in permanent deferral of blood donors due to the risk of transmitting these bloodborne pathogens. Blood donation guidelines prioritize recipient safety, and these infections pose a significant risk even with treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Travel to a malaria-endemic area (Option A): Travel to malaria-endemic areas typically results in a temporary deferral (e.g., 12 months) if no symptoms or diagnosis occur.

Tattoo or piercing within the last 12 months (Option B): Tattoos or piercings lead to a temporary deferral (e.g., 6-12 months) due to infection risk, not permanent deferral.

History of cancer (Option C): Cancer history may result in temporary or permanent deferral depending on the type and treatment status, but it is not universally permanent like HIV/HCV.

Reference: NACO GUIDELINES.

questions.text: The correct sequence for the disaster cycle is:
questions.solution:
This sequence follows the logical progression of disaster management:

  1. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the impact of potential disasters.
  2. Preparedness: Planning and preparation for potential disasters.
  3. Response: Immediate actions taken during and after a disaster.
  4. Rehabilitation: Recovery and rebuilding efforts after the disaster.

So, the correct answer is A.

Key Takeaways:

The sequence for disaster cycle: Mitigation → Preparedness → Response → Rehabilitation

questions.text: A 20 year old man steps into an elevator full of people who are coughing and sneezing, all of whom appear to have colds or the flu. The influenza viral particles that he inhales attach to respiratory epithelium, and viral transformation reduces the MHC class I molecules on these epithelial cells. Which of the following cells likely to respond to destroy the infected cells?
questions.solution:
• Influenza virus infection reduces MHC class I molecule expression on infected respiratory epithelial cells, impairing recognition by cytotoxic T cells.
  • Natural killer (NK) cells are critical in this scenario because they can detect and destroy cells with low MHC class I expression.
  • NK cells carry inhibitory receptors (e.g., KIRs) that bind MHC class I; when MHC class I is reduced, these inhibitory signals are lost, activating NK cells to kill the infected cells via perforin and granzyme release. This makes NK cells a key first-line defence against viral infections.

Explanation of other options:

Neutrophils (Option B) primarily target extracellular bacteria and fungi through phagocytosis and release of antimicrobial substances. They are not effective against intracellular viral infections like influenza, which require cell-mediated cytotoxicity.

CD4 cells (Option C): CD4+ T-helper cells orchestrate immune responses by activating other immune cells (e.g., B cells, cytotoxic T cells) via cytokine secretion. They do not directly destroy infected cells, unlike NK cells or cytotoxic T cells.

Macrophages (Option D) phagocytose apoptotic or necrotic cells and process antigens for presentation, but are not primarily responsible for directly killing virus-infected cells with reduced MHC class I expression.

Key Takeaways:

When expression of class I MHC molecules is reduced on the cell surface, the inhibitory receptors on NK cells do not receive a negative signal, and the cell is killed.

choices.text: Obstructive uropathy secondary to crystallization of calcium phosphate

questions.text: A diagnosed case of multiple myeloma is started on dexamethasone. Five days after starting therapy, he develops decreased urine output. Evaluation shows hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia, and raised serum urea and creatinine. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1. Serum creatine phosphokinase is 150 U/L (normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation with acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia, and a urinary uric acid to creatinine ratio >1, five days after starting dexamethasone for multiple myeloma, is consistent with tumour lysis syndrome (TLS).

Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS):

  • Characterised by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia and is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. Acute renal failure occurs frequently.
  • TLS is most often associated with the treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • TLS usually occurs during or shortly (1-5 days) after chemotherapy. The finding of uric acid crystals in the urine is strong evidence for uric acid nephropathy.
  • The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1 in patients with acute hyperuricemic nephropathy and <1 in patients with renal failure due to other causes. Other events may lead to renal failure in TLS.
  • Calcium phosphate also precipitates in the interstitium and renal microvasculature, leading to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure may rapidly become life-threatening by causing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.
  • The likelihood that TLS will occur in patients with Burkitt's lymphoma is related to the tumour burden and renal function. Hyperuricemia and high serum levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH >1500 U/L), both of which correlate with total tumour burden, also correlate with the risk of TLS.
  • The standard preventive approach consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is no longer recommended. Febuxostat, a potent nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is indicated for the treatment of hyperuricemia.
  • Rasburicase(recombinant urate oxidase) can be effective in these instances, particularly when renal failure is present. Rasburicase should also be administered to high-risk patients for TLS prophylaxis.
  • Despite aggressive prophylaxis, TLS and/or oliguric or anuric renal failure may occur. Renal replacement therapy is often necessary and should be considered early in the course. Hemodialysis is preferred. Hemofiltration offers a gradual, continuous method of removing cellular by-products and fluid.

Explanation of other options:

Rhabdomyolysis (Option B) causes acute renal failure with markedly elevated creatine phosphokinase (often >1000 U/L) due to muscle breakdown, releasing myoglobin. The normal creatine phosphokinase level (150 U/L) makes this unlikely.

Obstructive uropathy secondary to crystallisation of calcium phosphate (Option C): While calcium phosphate precipitation can occur in TLS, the primary driver of renal failure here is uric acid nephropathy, as evidenced by the urinary uric acid to creatinine ratio >1. Obstructive uropathy alone does not explain the full electrolyte profile.

Both A and C (Option D): TLS (Option A) is sufficient to explain the findings; there is no evidence of obstructive uropathy as a distinct entity, as the renal failure is primarily due to uric acid nephropathy.

choices.text: Do not worry, give the vaccine
Discard the vial, and use another new vial
Use the vaccine, but give a double dose
Keep in freezer. Will use tomorrow

questions.text: For giving opv vaccine, the worker took out opv vial from ice ice-lined refrigerator. Suddenly, he noticed that the colour of the inner square of the vaccine vial monitor is dark purple. He asked his senior doctor about this. What could be the advice of a senior doctor?
questions.solution:
• The colour change in the vaccine vial monitor (VVM), which indicates that the inner square has turned dark purple, suggests that the vaccine has been exposed to inappropriate temperatures (either too high or too low) and may no longer be effective.
  • OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is sensitive to temperature changes, and its efficacy can be compromised if it has been stored outside the recommended temperature range. The VVM helps to ensure the vaccine is still potent.
  • Giving a vaccine is not appropriate because using a vaccine with a changed VVM colour could result in ineffective vaccination.
  • Using a vaccine but giving a double dose is also not recommended, as it does not address the issue of potential ineffectiveness due to improper storage.
  • Keeping it in the freezer and using it tomorrow is not a solution because the vaccine should not be stored in a freezer, and the colour change indicates that the vaccine might already be compromised.
  • Thus, the safest course of action is to discard the vial and use a new, properly stored vial to ensure the vaccine's efficacy and safety.

Summary of the stages of a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM):

Explanations of other options:

Do not worry, give vaccine (Option A): Administering a vaccine with a dark purple VVM is unsafe, as it may be ineffective, failing to provide immunity and potentially compromising vaccination efforts.

Use vaccine but give double dose (Option C): Doubling the dose of a potentially ineffective vaccine does not restore its potency and is not recommended, as it may also increase the risk of adverse effects.

Keep in freezer, will use tomorrow (Option D): Storing OPV in a freezer (below 0°C) can further damage the vaccine, as it is not meant to be frozen. The dark purple VVM already indicates the vial is compromised.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle in a given image?
questions.solution:
The muscle seen in the image is the Masseter muscle. Its primary actions are elevation (closing the jaw) and protrusion (forward movement of the mandible), essential for chewing and biting.
