questions.text: What is recommended dilution and route of administration of adrenaline in case of anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
• For anaphylaxis, the first-line treatment is 3-0.5 mL of 1:1000 epinephrine (1 mg/mL) administered intramuscularly in the anterolateral thigh, with repeat doses every 5-20 minutes as needed.
  • Intramuscular administration ensures rapid absorption and reversal of anaphylactic symptoms.
  • Early administration (within 20 minutes) is critical to prevent poor outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

0.3-0.5 mL of 1:1000 epinephrine, subcutaneous (Option B): Subcutaneous administration is less effective due to slower absorption, especially in shock states with poor peripheral perfusion.

0.3-0.5 mL of 1:10000 epinephrine, intramuscular (Option C): The 1:10000 dilution (0.1 mg/mL) is used for intravenous administration in cardiac arrest, not for intramuscular use in anaphylaxis.

0.3-0.5 mL of 1:10000 epinephrine, subcutaneous (Option D): This dilution and route are inappropriate for anaphylaxis due to insufficient dosing and slower absorption.

questions.text: A 19 year old woman has a history of asthma for 10 years. She was brought to the medicine department with complaints of an acute onset of wheezing. Which of the following drugs would be the best for treatment of an acute attack of asthma?
questions.solution:
Inhaled albuterol, a short-acting β2-agonist, is the first-line treatment for acute asthma attacks. It rapidly induces bronchodilation by stimulating G-protein-coupled receptors, increasing cAMP, relaxing smooth muscles, and reducing mediator release.

Adrenergic drugs (β2 agonists) act by:

  • Stimulating GPCRs - Activation of adenylyl cyclase - Increase in cAMP
    • smooth muscle relaxation(bronchodilation)
    • Decreases the mediator release from mast cells.
    • Inhibit microvascular leakage
    • Increase mucociliary transport by increasing ciliary activity.
  • By inhalation route, these are the fastest acting drugs.
  • Salbutamol (albuterol), metaproterenol, and terbutaline are fast acting drugs by inhalation route. They are used for aborting an attack of acute asthma.
  • Not suitable for prophylaxis because of the shorter duration of action.

Explanation of other options:

Oral albuterol (Option B): Oral albuterol has a slower onset and is less effective for acute asthma, as it lacks the rapid, targeted action of inhaled delivery.

Oral dexamethasone (Option C): Corticosteroids like dexamethasone reduce inflammation but have a delayed onset (hours), making them adjunctive, not primary, for acute attacks.

Oral salmeterol (Option D): Salmeterol is a long-acting β2-agonist used for maintenance therapy, not for acute attacks due to its slow onset and prolonged duration.

Key Takeaway: Inhaled albuterol provides rapid, localised bronchodilation, making it the best treatment for acute asthma attacks.

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with a 3 cm staghorn calculus in the renal pelvis causing recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the best surgical approach for this stone?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the preferred treatment for staghorn calculi (>2 cm) and complex renal stones.

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL):

  • A minimally invasive surgical procedure where a nephroscope is inserted through a small incision in the back to access the kidney.
  • Stones are removed or fragmented using ultrasonic or laser lithotripsy.
  • Indications:
    • Large stones (>2 cm)
    • Staghorn calculi
    • Complex renal anatomy
    • Failed less invasive treatments
  • Contraindications:
    • Pregnancy
    • Untreated UTI
    • Bleeding diathesis
    • Current anticoagulation
  • Advantages: High success rate, shorter recovery time compared to open surgery.
  • Complications: Bleeding, infection, injury to adjacent organs, and residual stone fragments.

Explanation of other options:

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) (Option A) is less effective for large (>2 cm) or staghorn calculi due to incomplete fragmentation and high recurrence rates.

Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) (Option B) is suitable for smaller stones (<2 cm) but is less effective for large staghorn calculi due to limited access and clearance.

Open nephrolithotomy (Option D) is rarely used today, reserved for cases where minimally invasive techniques fail or are contraindicated, due to higher morbidity and longer recovery.

Key Takeaway:

PCNL is the most effective and preferred method for large staghorn calculi, offering high clearance rates and shorter recovery compared to open surgery.

questions.text: A 18-month-old child presented to paediatric OPD with ambiguous genitalia, on investigation his BP is 110/70 mm Hg, Serum potassium is 6.5 mEq/L, serum sodium is 115 mEq/L. He was later started on intravenous fluids. What is the most specific therapy will you add to this patient immediately?
questions.solution:
• The presentation of ambiguous genitalia, hyperkalemia (potassium 6.5 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (sodium 115 mEq/L) strongly suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most commonly 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Hydrocortisone, a glucocorticoid with significant mineralocorticoid activity, is the first-line treatment to replace deficient hormones, suppress ACTH, and correct electrolyte imbalances.

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (Adrenogenital Syndrome):

  • It is a familial disorder due to genetic deficiency of steroidogenic enzymes, mostly 21-hydroxylase.
  • As a result the synthesis of hydrocortisone and aldosterone suffers.
  • There is compensatory increase in ACTH secretion causing adrenocortical hypertrophy.
  • Enzyme deficiency being only partial in most cases, normal amounts of gluco- and mineralocorticoids are produced along with excessive amounts of weak androgens which produce virilisation and/or precocious sexual development.
  • Treatment is to give hydrocortisone in divided doses round the clock to maintain feedback suppression of pituitary.
  • If salt wasting persists-fludrocortisone 50-200 μg/day may be added.

Explanation of other options:

Potassium-binding resin (Option B): This treats hyperkalemia symptomatically but does not address the underlying CAH or hyponatremia.

Digoxin (Option C) is used for heart failure or arrhythmias, not relevant to CAH or its electrolyte abnormalities.

Calcium gluconate (Option D) is used for acute hyperkalemia with ECG changes to stabilise cardiac membranes, but it does not treat the underlying CAH.

Key Takeaway:

Hydrocortisone is the most specific therapy for CAH, addressing glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiencies and correcting electrolyte imbalances.

questions.text: A 45 year old female is found unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. To open her airway, what is the most appropriate manoeuvre to use if there is no suspicion of a cervical spine injury?
questions.solution:
The head tilt, chin lift manoeuvre is the first-line technique to open the airway in an unconscious patient without suspected cervical spine injury. It is contraindicated in suspected cervical spine injury, where the jaw thrust manoeuvre is preferred.

Head Tilt, Chin Lift Manoeuvre:

Purpose:

  • Head Tilt, Chin Lift: A technique used to open the airway in an unconscious patientby preventing the tongue from obstructing the airway.

Indications:

  • Unconscious Patients: Particularly those without a suspected cervical spine injury.
  • Airway Obstruction: Due to the tongue falling back against the pharynx, common in unconscious patients.

Technique:

  • Head Tilt:Place one hand on the patient's forehead and gently tilt the head back.
  • Chin Lift: Use the fingertips of your other hand to lift the chin upwards and forwards.

Contraindications:

  • Suspected Cervical Spine Injury: In such cases, the jaw thrustmanoeuvre should be used instead, as it does not involve movement of the cervical spine.

Complications:

  • Exacerbation of Cervical Spine Injury
  • Inadequate Airway Opening

Explanation of other options:

Jaw thrust manoeuvre (Option A) is used when cervical spine injury is suspected, as it opens the airway without moving the neck.

Nasopharyngeal airway insertion (Option B) is an adjunct device, not the initial manoeuvre, used when airway obstruction persists.

Oropharyngeal airway insertion (Option D) is an adjunct device, not the first-line manoeuvre, and is used in unconscious patients to maintain airway patency.

Key Takeaway:

The head tilt, chin lift manoeuvre is the preferred method for opening the airway in unconscious patients without suspected cervical spine injury.

questions.text: Hypertriglyceridemia is considered a risk factor for acute pancreatitis. At what serum levels of serum triglycerides it usually causes acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
• Hypertriglyceridemia is the cause of acute pancreatitis in 1-4% of cases; serum triglyceride levels are usually >1000 mg/dL. Most patients with hypertriglyceridemia and pancreatitis have undiagnosed or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
  • Any factor (e.g., alcohol or medications, such as oral contraceptives) that causes an abrupt increase in serum triglycerides can potentially precipitate a bout of acute pancreatitis.
  • Common causes of acute pancreatitis include:
    • Gallstones (including microlithiasis)
    • Alcohol (acute or chronic)
    • Hypertriglyceridemia
    • Post ERCP
    • Idiopathic

questions.text: A 50 year old male is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is hypotensive, bradycardic, and has warm extremities. His physical exam reveals flaccid paralysis below the level of T6. What type of shock is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock, a type of distributive shock, results from loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury above T6. It presents with hypotension, bradycardia (due to unopposed parasympathetic activity), and warm, dry skin (due to vasodilation).

Spinal Shock vs. Neurogenic Shock:

Explanation of other options:

Hypovolemic shock (Option A): This presents with hypotension, tachycardia, and cool, clammy skin due to blood loss, not bradycardia or warm extremities.

Cardiogenic shock (Option B): This involves hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of heart failure (e.g., pulmonary oedema), not flaccid paralysis or bradycardia.

Spinal shock (Option C): This refers to a temporary loss of neurological function (motor, sensory, reflexes) below the injury level, not directly causing hemodynamic instability like neurogenic shock.

Key Takeaway: Neurogenic shock, caused by spinal cord injury above T6, leads to hypotension, bradycardia, and warm extremities due to loss of sympathetic tone.

questions.text:
A patient presents with a skin lesion that has a black eschar. The Gram stain image shows large, Gram-positive rods with square ends and a characteristic "boxcar" appearance.

Which bacterial species is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is characterised by large, Gram-positive rods with square ends and a "boxcar" appearance on Gram stain. Cutaneous anthrax presents with a painless black eschar, often with surrounding oedema, as described.

Explanation of other options:

Bacillus cereus (Option B): This Gram-positive rod causes food poisoning or soft tissue infections but lacks the "boxcar" appearance and black eschar.

Clostridium botulinum (Option C): This Gram-positive rod causes botulism, not cutaneous lesions with black eschar, and lacks the "boxcar" appearance.

Clostridium perfringens (Option D): This Gram-positive rod causes gas gangrene or food poisoning, not black eschar or "boxcar" morphology.

Key Takeaway:

Bacillus anthracis is associated with cutaneous anthrax, presenting with a black eschar and Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of compensated cirrhosis of liver?
questions.solution:
• Compensated cirrhosis is characterised by stable liver function without clinical complications.
  • Decompensated cirrhosis involves complications like ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, and variceal bleeding due to portal hypertension.
  • Thus, none of the listed options (ascites, portal hypertension, hepatic encephalopathy) are features of compensated cirrhosis.

choices.text: Plasmids do not influence bacterial virulence and only carry genes for replication
Plasmids can encode toxins and virulence factors that enhance the pathogenicity of bacteria
Plasmids are exclusively responsible for bacterial growth and replication but do not affect virulence
Plasmids act as structural components of the bacterial cell wall

questions.text: What role do plasmids play in bacterial virulence?
questions.solution:
Plasmids are small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecules that replicate independently of chromosomal DNA. They often carry genes for toxins, adhesins, or other virulence factors that enhance bacterial pathogenicity (e.g., toxin production in Escherichia coli or antibiotic resistance).

Role of Plasmids in Bacterial Virulence:

Explanation of other options:

Plasmids do not influence bacterial virulence and only carry genes for replication (Option A): Plasmids carry various genes, including those for virulence, not just replication.

Plasmids are exclusively responsible for bacterial growth and replication but do not affect virulence (Option C): While plasmids may carry replication genes, they also encode virulence factors, impacting pathogenicity.

Plasmids act as structural components of the bacterial cell wall (Option D): Plasmids are DNA molecules, not structural components of the cell wall.

Key Takeaway:

Plasmids enhance bacterial virulence by encoding toxins and other factors that increase pathogenicity.

questions.text: A long standing diabetic patient has eGFR of 34 ml/min and Urinary albumin creatinine ratio is 100 mg/mmol for last 6 months. What is the stage of chronic kidney disease he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
• CKD staging per KDIGO classification combines eGFR (glomerular filtration rate) and albuminuria.
  • An eGFR of 34 mL/min/1.73 m² corresponds to G3b (30-44 mL/min).
  • A urinary albumin-creatinine ratio of 100 mg/mmol (equivalent to 1000 mg/g) indicates A3 (severe albuminuria, >30 mg/mmol or >300 mg/g). Thus, the stage is G3bA3.

KDIGO Classification:

questions.text: What is the primary vector responsible for transmitting dengue virus to humans?
questions.solution:
The Aedes mosquito, specifically Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, is the primary vector for dengue virus transmission. These mosquitoes bite during the day and thrive in urban environments, contributing to dengue spread.

Explanation of other options:

Anopheles mosquito (Option A) transmits malaria, not dengue, and typically bites at night.

Culex mosquito (Option C) transmits West Nile virus and filariasis, not dengue.

Tsetse fly (Option D) transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not dengue.

Key Takeaway:

Aedes mosquitoes are the primary vectors for dengue.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation of choice for malignancy screening in patients of longstanding inflammatory bowel disease?
questions.solution:
Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice for malignancy screening in long-standing IBD (e.g., ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease) due to the increased risk of colorectal cancer. It allows direct visualisation, biopsy of suspicious lesions, and surveillance every 1-2 years after 8-10 years of disease.

Explanation of other options:

Sigmoidoscopy (Option A): Limited to the distal colon, missing proximal lesions, making it inadequate for comprehensive IBD screening.

Contrast CT abdomen (Option C): Useful for assessing complications but not specific for mucosal malignancy screening.

Endoscopic ultrasound (Option D): Used for staging rectal cancers, not for routine IBD malignancy screening.

Key Takeaway:

Colonoscopy is the gold standard for colorectal cancer screening in IBD due to its ability to visualise and biopsy the entire colon.

questions.text:
40-year-old male presents with hematuria and proteinuria. Urine microscopy reveals:

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs) and red cell casts on urine microscopy indicate glomerular damage, characteristic of glomerulonephritis, a group of diseases causing glomerular inflammation. This can include conditions like IgA nephropathy, but the broad term "glomerulonephritis" encompasses the findings.

Explanation of other options:

  • IgA nephropathy (Option A): A specific form of glomerulonephritis with IgA deposits, often presenting with hematuria and proteinuria, but the question's broad findings favour the general term.
  • Alport syndrome (Option B): A genetic disorder with hematuria and hearing/vision issues, but red cell casts are less common, and it's not the best fit.
  • Thin basement membrane disease (Option C): Causes benign hematuria without red cell casts or significant proteinuria, not matching the findings.

Key Takeaway:

Dysmorphic RBCs and red cell casts indicate glomerulonephritis, a broad category of glomerular inflammatory diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for treatment of chronic hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Entecavir is a nucleoside analogue used for chronic hepatitis B, inhibiting viral DNA polymerase to reduce viral replication. Dasabuvir, ledipasvir, and sofosbuvir are used for hepatitis C.

Drugs used for the management of chronic Hep B include:

  • Lamivudine
  • Adefovir
  • Entecavir
  • Telbivudine
  • Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate or Tenofovir Alafenamide

questions.text: Match the following vacutainer with their corresponding uses:
Estimation of which of the following in stool is useful for diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency in a patient presenting with steatorrhea?
questions.solution:
• Faecal elastase is a specific, non-invasive test for pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, measuring pancreatic enzyme output.
  • Low levels indicate impaired pancreatic function, common in conditions like chronic pancreatitis or cystic fibrosis, causing steatorrhea.

Explanation of other options:

24-hour faecal fat estimation (Option A): Quantifies steatorrhea but is not specific for pancreatic insufficiency, as it can occur in other malabsorption disorders.

Faecal tryptase (Option B): Not a standard test for pancreatic insufficiency; it is more relevant for mast cell disorders.

D-Xylose (Option D): Tests small intestinal absorption, not pancreatic function, and is irrelevant for steatorrhea diagnosis.

Key Takeaway:

Faecal elastase is the preferred test for diagnosing pancreatic insufficiency in steatorrhea, being specific and practical.

choices.text: Thick ascending loop of Henle in the kidney
Pulmonary epithelial cells in the lungs

questions.text: ENaC channel is not found in
questions.solution:
• Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) facilitate sodium reabsorption in various tissues, including taste buds (salty taste sensation) and pulmonary epithelial cells (sodium and fluid absorption at birth).
  • In the kidney, ENaC is found in the collecting duct, regulated by aldosterone, but not in the thick ascending loop of Henle, which uses Na-K-Cl cotransporters and Na/H exchangers.
  • At birth, there is a shift from Cl- secretin to Na+ absorptionby pulmonary epithelial cells via the epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC), and fluid is absorbed with the Na+.
    • Prolonged immaturity of the ENaC contributes to the pulmonary abnormalities in IRDS.
  • The aldosterone (adrenocortical mineralocorticoid)has two effects in the collecting duct for Na+ reabsorption.
    • Rapid effect to increase the activity of ENaC channels by inserting the channels into the membrane.
    • A slower effect to increase the synthesis of ENaCs.
  • In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, Na-K-Cl cotransporter and Na/H exchanger.

Explanation of other options:

Taste buds in the tongue (Option A): ENaC channels are present, mediating salty taste perception.

Pulmonary epithelial cells in the lungs (Option C): ENaC channels facilitate sodium and fluid absorption, critical at birth.

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect, as ENaC is present in taste buds and pulmonary epithelium, but not in the thick ascending loop.

Key Takeaway:

ENaC channels are absent in the thick ascending loop of Henle, which relies on other sodium transport mechanisms.

questions.text: Rate of involution of uterus is:
questions.solution:
Uterine involution post-delivery involves the uterus returning to its non-pregnant size. The fundus, initially at the umbilicus, descends approximately 1.25 cm per day.

Rate of Uterine Involution:

  • Immediately after delivery: The Uterus is at the level of the umbilicus.
  • Day 1 postpartum: Fundus is approximately 1.25 cm below the umbilicus.
  • Daily reduction: The fundus descends about 1.25 cm per day.
  • End of 1 week: Fundus is typically midway between the umbilicus and the pubic symphysis.
  • End of 2 weeks: Uterus is no longer palpable abdominally.
  • By 6 weeks: The uterus returns to its non-pregnant size (around 60-80 grams).

This steady descent continues until the uterus reaches its normal size and position by about 6 weeks postpartum. Factors like breastfeeding (which increases oxytocin release), parity, and the presence of complications can influence this rate.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was taken to the pediatrician for routine checkup. Pediatrician evaluated him and found that he has autoimmune disorder causing damage to the small intestine. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten, causing T-cell-mediated damage to the small intestine's mucosa, leading to malabsorption.
  • Symptoms include diarrhoea, weight loss, and nutrient deficiencies, reversible with a gluten-free diet.

Explanation of other options:

Lactose intolerance (Option A): A non-autoimmune condition due to lactase deficiency, causing diarrhoea and bloating, not small intestine damage.

Hartnup disease (Option B): A genetic defect in neutral amino acid transport, not autoimmune, causing pellagra-like symptoms, not intestinal damage.

Cystinuria (Option D): A genetic defect in basic amino acid transport, leading to kidney stones, not autoimmune or intestinal damage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is considering starting a hormonal contraceptive but is concerned about its effect on her bone density. Which of the following is the most likely hormonal method to affect bone density?
questions.solution:
• Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), a progestin-only injectable contraceptive, is associated with decreased bone mineral density, particularly with long-term use (>2 years), due to suppression of estrogen levels.
  • This effect is reversible upon discontinuation, but is significant compared to other methods.

Explanation of other options:

Combined oral contraceptive pill (Option A): Contains estrogen and progestin, generally neutral or protective for bone density due to estrogen's bone-preserving effects.

Contraceptive patch (Option B): Delivers estrogen and progestin, similar to oral pills, with no significant negative impact on bone density.

Contraceptive implant (Option D): Releases progestin (etonogestrel), with minimal impact on bone density compared to DMPA.

Key Takeaway:

DMPA is the hormonal contraceptive most likely to reduce bone density, especially with prolonged use.

questions.text: A patient has been suffering from Acute Diarrhea since 03 days. Identify the correct Acid Base Imbalance from the above diagram the patient is suffering from.
questions.solution:
• Acute diarrhoea causes loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid from the gastrointestinal tract, leading to metabolic acidosis (pH <7.35, HCO3 <22 mmol/L).
  • Chloride is reabsorbed to maintain electroneutrality, keeping the anion gap normal.
  • The respiratory system compensates via hyperventilation to reduce PaCO2.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory acidosis (Option A): Caused by increased PaCO2 (hypoventilation), with normal or elevated HCO3, due to renal compensation, not relevant to diarrhoea.

Metabolic alkalosis (Option B): Caused by increased HCO3 (e.g., vomiting), with pH >7.45 and respiratory hypoventilation, opposite to diarrhoea's effects.

Respiratory alkalosis (Option D): Caused by decreased PaCO2 (hyperventilation), with pH >7.45 and reduced HCO3, via renal compensation, not caused by diarrhoea.

Key Takeaway:

Acute diarrhoea causes metabolic acidosis due to bicarbonate loss, with respiratory compensation via hyperventilation.

questions.text: A 34 year old male presents to the emergency department with sudden chest pain and severe shortness of breath after being involved in a road traffic accident. On examination, he has tracheal deviation to the left, hyperresonance on the right side, and absent breath sounds on the right. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The findings of tracheal deviation, hyperresonance, and absent breath sounds suggest tension pneumothorax, a life-threatening condition where air trapped in the pleural space compresses the lung and mediastinum. Immediate needle decompression (14-16 gauge needle in the fifth intercostal space, midclavicular line) is required, followed by chest tube insertion.

Tension Pneumothorax:

  • Pathophysiology: Air enters the pleural space during inspiration but cannot escape during expiration, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  • Complications:This pressure shift compresses the lung and mediastinal structures, leading to decreased venous return, reduced cardiac output, and potential cardiovascular collapse.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms:Sudden onset of chest pain and severe dyspnea.
    • Signs:Tracheal deviation away from the affected side, hyperresonance to percussion, absent breath sounds on the affected side, and distended neck veins.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical Diagnosis:Based on physical examination findings; should not delay treatment.
    • Imaging: While a chest X-ray can confirm the diagnosis, it is not required before initiating emergency treatment.
  • Management:
    • Immediate Needle Decompression:Insert a large bore needle (14-16 gauge) into the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line of the affected side to relieve pressure.
    • Chest Tube Insertion:Following needle decompression, a chest tube should be placed to allow continuous evacuation of air and reexpansion of the lung.

Explanation of other options:

Chest X-ray (Option B): Confirms diagnosis but delays treatment in a life-threatening emergency.

High-flow oxygen administration (Option C): Improves oxygenation but does not address the underlying pressure from pneumothorax.

IV antibiotics (Option D): Not indicated acutely, as infection is not the primary issue.

Key Takeaway:

Tension pneumothorax requires immediate needle decompression to prevent cardiovascular collapse, followed by chest tube placement.

questions.text: A -30 years old Male presented with above cutaneous manifestation on sun exposed areas along with increase in urine uroporphyrin levels, what should be your probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), the most common porphyria, is caused by uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency, leading to uroporphyrin accumulation.
  • It presents with photosensitive skin eruptions (blisters, scarring) on sun-exposed areas, often triggered by hepatic iron overload, alcohol, estrogen, or sunlight.
  • Increased urine uroporphyrin is diagnostic.

Explanation of other options:

Acute intermittent porphyria (Option A): A hepatic porphyria with neurological symptoms (abdominal pain, neuropathy), not photosensitive skin lesions or uroporphyrinuria.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (Option B): A rare porphyria with severe photosensitivity and hemolytic anaemia, but uroporphyrin is elevated in both urine and faeces, not just urine.

Variegate porphyria (Option D): Presents with skin and neurological symptoms, but urine coproporphyrin and protoporphyrin are more prominent than uroporphyrin.

Key Takeaway:

PCT is characterised by photosensitive skin lesions and elevated urine uroporphyrin due to uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency.

questions.text: A 40 year old male is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the chest. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, and has distended neck veins. Muffled heart sounds are noted on auscultation. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The presentation of hypotension, tachycardia, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad) indicates cardiac tamponade, likely from hemopericardium due to penetrating chest trauma. Pericardiocentesis is the immediate life-saving procedure to relieve pericardial pressure.

Cardiac Tamponade:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Mechanism:Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac leads to increased intrapericardial pressure, which compresses the heart and restricts its ability to fill during diastole.
  • Complications:If untreated, cardiac tamponade can lead to obstructive shockand death due to inadequate cardiac output.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Beck's Triad: Hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds
    • Other Signs:Pulsus paradoxus (a drop in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration), tachycardia, and signs of shock.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical Diagnosis:Based on physical examination findings.
    • Echocardiogram:The gold standard for diagnosing cardiac tamponade, as it can visualise fluid in the pericardial sac and assess its impact on cardiac function.
  • Management:
    • Pericardiocentesis: Immediate needle aspiration of the pericardial fluid to relieve pressure on the heart.
    • Surgical Management:In cases of myocardial trauma, thoracotomy may be needed if pericardiocentesis is ineffective or if there is ongoing bleeding.

Explanation of other options:

Chest X-ray (Option A): May show an enlarged cardiac silhouette but delays life-saving intervention.

Immediate thoracotomy (Option C): Indicated if pericardiocentesis fails or ongoing bleeding is suspected, but not the first step.

Administration of IV fluids (Option D): Temporarily supports blood pressure but does not address the underlying tamponade.

Key Takeaway:

Cardiac tamponade, identified by Beck's triad, requires urgent pericardiocentesis to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and hepatomegaly. Imaging studies reveal a large, heterogeneous liver mass. Biopsy confirms Hepatic Angiosarcoma. All of the following exposures are associated with this except?
questions.solution:
Hepatic angiosarcoma, a rare endothelial cell malignancy, is associated with exposures to thorium dioxide (Thorotrast), vinyl chloride (polyvinyl chloride), arsenic, and anabolic steroids. Iron overload (hemochromatosis) is linked to hepatocellular carcinoma, not angiosarcoma.

Several environmental and chemical exposures have been associated with an increased risk:

  1. Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast): Historically used as a contrast agent in radiology, it has been linked to a high incidence of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  2. Vinyl chloride: A chemical used in the production of plastics has been strongly associated with hepatic angiosarcoma.
  3. Arsenic: Chronic exposure to arsenic has been implicated in the development of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  4. Anabolic steroids: Long-term use of anabolic steroids may increase the risk.

Key Takeaway:

Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with arsenic, Thorotrast, and polyvinyl chloride, but not iron overload.

choices.text: It increases the risk of renal cell carcinoma.
It causes frequent urinary tract infections.
It typically results in renal failure by the age of 50.

questions.text: A 45 year old male is incidentally diagnosed with a horseshoe kidney during an abdominal ultrasound for unrelated reasons. Which statement is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Horseshoe kidney, a congenital fusion of the lower renal poles, increases the risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) due to urinary stasis and vesicoureteral reflux.

Horseshoe Kidney:

  • A congenital condition where the lower poles of the kidneys are fused,typically located lower in the abdomen.
  • Prevalence:
    • Occurs in about 1 in 400 individuals, more common in males.
  • The isthmus lies at the level of the fourth to fifth lumbar vertebrae(fused lower poles). This causes failure to ascend and rotate so that the renal pelvis faces anteriorly and vertically, with the malrotated calyces pointing posteromedially.
  • Complications:
    • Increased risk of UTIs, kidney stones, and hydronephrosis due to altered renal drainage and urinary stasis.
    • Associated with Turner syndrome
  • Management:
    • Often conservative, focusing on managing UTIs and monitoring kidney function.
    • Surgical intervention is rare.

Explanation of other options:

Increases risk of renal cell carcinoma (Option A): Incorrect, as a horseshoe kidney is more associated with Wilms’ tumour in children, not renal cell carcinoma.

Associated with hypertension (Option B): Incorrect, as hypertension is not a direct consequence of a horseshoe kidney.

Results in renal failure by age 50 (Option D): Incorrect, as most patients have normal renal function unless complicated by stones or infections.

Key Takeaway:

Horseshoe kidney predisposes to frequent UTIs due to urinary stasis, but most patients maintain normal renal function.

choices.text: To allow damaged cells to repair DNA
To permit cells to enter quiescence
To regulate cell growth and division

questions.text: What is the primary function of the G1 checkpoint in the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division

The G1 checkpoint ensures that a cell is ready to enter the S phase of the cell cycle by checking:

  1. Cell Size: Ensures the cell has grown enough to divide.
  2. DNA Integrity: Detects and repairs DNA damage or triggers apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.
  3. Nutrient Availability: Confirms sufficient nutrients and energy are present.
  4. Growth Signals: Responds to external growth factors needed for division.
  5. Quiescence Decision: Determines whether to proceed or enter a resting state (G0).

Key regulators include p53 (DNA damage response), Cyclins/CDKs, and Retinoblastoma (Rb). If conditions are favorable, the cell moves into the S phase for DNA replication.

  1. The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.
  2. G2 checkpoint allows damaged cells to repair DNA.
  3. Chromosome segregation occurs during mitosis.
  4. Quiescence is a state of dormancy that can occur outside of the cell cycle.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.

questions.text: All of the following arteries form circle of Willis except
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis (Circulus Arteriosus): It is six sided polygonal of arteries formed at base of brain by branches of basilar and internal carotid arteries.

It is formed around the interpeduncular fossa and lies in the interpeduncular cistern.

Formation of circle of Willis:

  • Anteriorly: By anterior cerebral and anterior communicating arteries (Option A,D)
  • Posteriorly: By the basilar artery dividing into two posterior cerebral arteries
  • Laterally on each side: By posterior communicating artery connecting internal carotid artery with the posterior cerebral artery..(Option C)

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with right flank pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging following appearance of the proximal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Retrocaval ureter anomaly results in the ureter looping behind the inferior vena cava, creating a "fishhook" or "reverse J" appearance on imaging.

  • Retrocaval Ureter:
    • A congenital anomaly where the ureter passes posterior to the inferior vena cava, leading to a characteristic "fish hook" appearance.
  • Symptoms:
    • Flank pain, hematuria, recurrent UTIs due to partial ureteral obstruction.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging studies such as intravenous urography or CT scan showing the path of the ureter behind the IVC.
  • Management:
    • Surgical correction to reposition the ureter anterior to the IVC to relieve obstruction.

Horseshoe kidney (Option A):This congenital condition results in the fusion of the kidneys but does not cause a "fish hook" appearance of the ureter.

Ureterocele (Option B): Ureterocele appears as a cystic dilation at the distal ureter rather than a retrocaval positioning.

UPJ obstruction (Option D): UPJ obstruction typically presents with hydronephrosis, but not the specific retrocaval positioning seen in this case.

Key Takeaway:

  • Retrocaval ureter presents with a characteristic "fishhook" appearance on imaging.
  • Surgical repositioning is often required to relieve symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presents with sudden, severe loin pain relieved by urination. He has a history of intermittent episodes of similar pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dietl's crisis involves sudden severe pain in the loin, often associated with hydronephrosis, and is relieved by urination.

Dietl's Crisis and Ureteropelvic Junction Obstruction (PUJO)

Dietl's crisis is a severe episode of flank pain associated with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (PUJO). PUJO is a common congenital condition where the ureter is narrowed at the point where it joins the renal pelvis, leading to obstruction of urine flow.

Congenital PUJO

  • Incidence: Approximately 1 in 500 live births.
  • Causes: Intrinsic obstruction due to muscular hypoplasia, high insertion of the ureter, or crossing aberrant vessels.
  • Prevalence: More common in males and on the left side.

Presentation

  • Infants and children: Often presents with a palpable flank mass.
  • Adults: May present with back or flank pain, recurrent pyelonephritis, or Dietl's crisis.
  • Dietl's crisis: Severe flank pain following excessive fluid intake, often relieved by passing a large amount of urine.

Diagnosis

  • Isotope diuretic renography: The preferred imaging test. A rising curve following furosemide administration, a T1/2max of greater than 20 minutes, and a differential function of less than 40% on the affected side suggest significant obstruction.

Management

  • Surgical intervention: Indicated for persistent pain, hypertension, hematuria, secondary renal calculi, or recurrent UTIs.
  • Anderson-Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty: The preferred surgical procedure, involving a wide funnelled,dependent anastomosis and excision of the redundant pelvis.

Renal colic (Option A):While renal colic presents with severe pain, it is usually not relieved by positional changes and is caused by the passage of a stone.

Appendicitis (Option B): Appendicitis pain typically begins around the umbilicus and then localises to the right lower quadrant, with no relief from positional change.

Acute cholecystitis (Option D):This condition causes right upper quadrant pain that does not change with movement and often radiates to the back or shoulder.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dietl's crisis is associated with urination that relieves the pain.
  • It often involves intermittent UPJ obstruction or nephroptosis.

choices.text: It activates the antithrombin III and acts as anticoagulant
It acts as calcium chelating agent
It lyses fibrin and fibrinogen to produce fibrin degradation product

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient had chest pain. He was immediately carried to emergency department. Immediate ECG finding suggest myocardial infarction. He was given Alteplase immediately. The mechanism by which helps?
questions.solution:
• Alteplase is a tissue plasminogen activator drug.
  • It is potent fibrinolytic and a potent tissue plasminogen activator.
  • It acts via following mechanism
  • Heparin is a naturally occurring anticoagulant that facilitates the action of antithrombin III.(Option B ruled out)
  • Chelating agents bind with the calcium and prevents clotting mechanism (dicumarol)(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A middle aged male undergoes spirometry for his respiratory symptoms. FEV1/FVC is 94%. Which of the following diseases should not be considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A preserved or elevated FEV1/FVC ratio (94%) excludes obstructive lung disease, indicating restriction,and all of the listed conditions (pulmonary fibrosis, myasthenia gravis, morbid obesity) can cause a restrictive pattern,so none should be excluded

FEV1/FVC<80% indicates airway disease

Since the ratio is more than 80% therefore restrictive diseases should be considered in the differential diagnosis.

choices.text: Stone Fragments in a renal stone
Multiple stone fragments in the ureter

questions.text: A 35 year old male with a history of recent extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) presents with flank pain and fever. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
"Steinstrasse," meaning "stone street," refers to a condition where multiple stone fragments align in the ureter following ESWL, potentially causing obstruction and symptoms.

Steinstrasse (Stone Street)

  • Steinstrasse refers to the alignment of multiple stone fragments in the ureter, a common complication postESWL. It can cause ureteral obstruction, leading to pain, infection, and hydronephrosis.
  • Symptoms: Flank pain, fever, and signs of urinary obstruction following ESWL.
  • Diagnosis: Imaging, typically noncontrast CT or X Ray, showing a chain of stone fragments within the ureter.
  • Management: Observation if asymptomatic, medical expulsive therapy, or intervention (ureteroscopy or additional ESWL) if symptomatic or obstructing.

Stone Fragments in Kidney (Option A): It ;Refers to Ureter and not kidney

Stone formation in the urethra (Option B): Steinstrasse refers to the ureter, not the urethra.

Multiple stone fragments in the ureter (Option C): "Steinstrasse," meaning "stone street," refers to a condition where multiple stone fragments align in the ureter following ESWL, potentially causing obstruction and symptoms.

Bilateral hydronephrosis (Option D):Steinstrasse is a unilateral condition affecting the ureter and does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Steinstrasse is a post ESWL complication characterised by stone fragments lining up in the ureter.
  • It may cause pain and obstruction, requiring medical or surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45 year old female with a 1.5 cm renal stone in the lower pole of the kidney is planned for minimally invasive stone removal. What procedure is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
RIRS is minimally invasive, using a flexible ureteroscope and laser lithotripsy to treat stones up to 2 cm, especially in the lower pole.

Retrograde Intrarenal Surgery (RIRS)

  • A minimally invasive procedure using a flexible ureteroscope inserted through the urethra to access the kidney. Stones are fragmented using laser lithotripsy.
  • Indications:
    • Stones up to 2 cm, especially in the lower pole where ESWL is less effective.
    • patients with bleeding disorders or obese patients where PCNL may be risky.
    • kyphoscoliosis
  • Advantages: Less invasive, shorter recovery time, and high success rates for lower pole stones.
  • Complications: Infection, bleeding, ureteral injury, and residual fragments.

Open Nephrolithotomy (Option D): An invasive procedure, reserved for cases where other methods have failed or are contraindicated.

Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) (Option B): Less effective for lower pole stones due to poor clearance rates.

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) (Option A): More invasive and typically reserved for larger or complex renal stones (>2 cm).

Key Takeaway:

  • RIRS is suitable for treating renal stones up to 2 cm, particularly in the lower pole.
  • It is less invasive than PCNL and has a high success rate for stone clearance.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female visited the primary care physician clinic due to breathing problems. Doctor examined her and did spirometry. The values are tidal volume - 260 ml, vital capacity - 2600 ml, FEV1/FVC - 80%. The probable diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution:
• There are two principle category of respiratory disorders
    1. obstructive lung disorders
    2. restrictive lung disorders
  • Here the values in the spirometry shows that this patient has reduced lung volume and capacity.
  • Tuberculosis shows the restrictive pattern in lung disorder due to fibrosis.
    • Reduced lung volumes with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio
    • Especially tidal volume and vital capacity are less.
  • Other options are-type of obstructive lung disorder in which
    • FEV1/FVC ratio is usually less than 70%
    • Tidal volume and vital capacity does not reduce usually.

Emphysema (Option A): A form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) characterized by damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs.

Chronic Bronchitis (Option C): A form of COPD characterized by chronic inflammation of the bronchi, leading to mucus production, airway narrowing, and airflow obstruction.

Cystic Fibrosis (Option D): A genetic disorder that affects the exocrine glands, leading to the production of thick mucus that can obstruct the airways and lead to recurrent infections, inflammation, and lung damage.

questions.text: Tram track sign and signet ring sign is seen in which of the following clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis is irreversible dilation of airways. It can be cylindrical, tubular (most common), Varicose vein or cystic.

Depending on distribution it can be focal or diffuse.

Typical radiological signs of bronchiectasis include:

  1. Tram track sign-can be seen on chest X-ray PA view but CT is more specific
  2. "signet-ring sign"-only seen on CT scan of chest and defined as a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 1.5 times that of the adjacent vessel)
  3. Lack of bronchial tapering (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cm from the pleural surface),
  4. Bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways, inspissated secretions (e.g., the "tree-in-bud" pattern), or cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Bronchial Asthma (Option A):Typically, chest X-rays are normal or may show hyperinflation in severe cases.

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) (Option B):: Chest X-rays may reveal hyperinflation, flattened diaphragms, and increased lung volumes.

Silicosis (Option C):Chest X-rays may show small, rounded opacities, predominantly in the upper zones.

questions.text: Most common cardiac lesion seen in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac lesion in pregnancy, often due to rheumatic heart disease. Pregnancy increases blood volume and cardiac output, which can worsen symptoms of mitral stenosis, such as pulmonary congestion and atrial fibrillation, posing risks to both the mother and fetus.

Mitral Regurgitation (Option A):Relatively common in pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output, which can exacerbate existing valve insufficiency. However, it is not the most common cardiac lesion; it usually presents as a functional or physiological regurgitation without significant hemodynamic compromise.

Aortic Stenosis (Option C) Less common in pregnancy compared to mitral valve lesions. Severe cases can pose significant risks due to fixed cardiac output that cannot meet the increased demands of pregnancy, but it is not the most prevalent condition.

Pulmonary Regurgitation (Option D): Typically mild and often clinically insignificant in pregnancy. It is generally well tolerated due to the low-pressure nature of the right side of the heart, and it is far less common as a primary cardiac lesion compared to mitral stenosis.

questions.text: The image below shows a microscopic view of a blood smear or a tissue sample showing filarial parasites. Based on the appearance and specific characteristics in the image, which parasite is depicted?
questions.solution:
It is identified by the presence of sheathed microfilariae with an undulating motion and no nuclei at the tip.


Wuchereria bancrofti is characterized by its sheathed microfilariae with an undulating motion, typically observed in blood samples. The sheathed structure and specific movement patterns are key identifiers.

Brugia malayi (Option B)also causes lymphatic filariasis and has sheathed microfilariae, but differs in some morphologic details compared to Wuchereria bancrofti.-It has 2 nuclei at it's tip.


Onchocerca volvulus (Option C) microfilariae are unsheathed and typically do not show the sheathed structure seen in Wuchereria bancrofti.

Loa loa (Option D) microfilariae are larger and unsheathed, exhibiting a cork-screw motion, which is different from the sheathed microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti.



Key Takeaway: Wuchereria bancrofti is identified by its sheathed microfilariae and undulating motion in blood samples, which is crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial species.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Filariasis. CDC Filariasis

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with a groin mass below the inguinal ligament that becomes more prominent with standing. You suspect a femoral hernia. Which structure forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal?
questions.solution:
The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal.

Femoral Canal

  • Location: The femoral canal lies medial to the femoral vein within the femoral sheath.
  • Contents: The canal contains lymphatic vessels, a lymph node (Cloquet's node), and loose connective tissue.
  • Function: It allows the femoral vein to expand and provides a pathway for lymphatic drainage from the lower limb.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior: Inguinal ligament
    • Posterior: Pectineal ligament
    • Medial: Lacunar ligament
    • Lateral: Femoral vein

Explanation of Options:

Femoral vein (Option A):The femoral vein is located lateral to the femoral canal.

Inguinal ligament (Option B):The inguinal ligament forms the superior boundary of the femoral canal.

Pectineal ligament (Option D): The pectineal ligament forms the posterior boundary of the femoral canal.

Key points:

The femoral canal is the site of femoral hernias, more common in women and prone to incarceration due to its narrow structure.

choices.text: External cephalic version and trial of vaginal delivery
External cephalic version followed by Caesarean section

questions.text: Ideal management of 37 weeks uncomplicated breech pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
External cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure performed at or after 37 weeks of gestation to turn the fetus from a breech position to a cephalic (head-down) position. The goal of ECV is to enable a vaginal delivery, reducing the need for a Caesarean section. If the ECV is successful and there are no contraindications, a trial of vaginal delivery can be offered. This option is ideal as it aims to promote a vaginal birth, which has fewer risks of complications associated with surgery. However, the success rate of ECV is variable, and it requires careful monitoring.

External cephalic version followed by Caesarean section (Option B): This option is less commonly recommended because if the ECV is successful, the primary goal is to proceed with a vaginal delivery. Planning a Caesarean section after a successful ECV is contradictory, as the intent of ECV is to avoid a surgical delivery. Caesarean section would be reserved if the ECV fails or if other complications arise that necessitate surgery.

Spontaneous vaginal delivery (Option C): While some breech presentations can be delivered vaginally, it requires careful selection of cases and an experienced team. Most guidelines recommend against spontaneous vaginal breech delivery in uncomplicated cases at term because of the increased risks for both mother and fetus, such as cord prolapse, head entrapment, and traumatic injury.

Caesarean section straightaway (Option D): This option is generally preferred in term breech pregnancies to avoid the complications associated with breech vaginal deliveries. While Caesarean section provides a controlled environment to reduce risks, it is not the ideal initial management if ECV is available and there are no contraindications to attempting a vaginal delivery.

Key takeaway: The ideal management for a 37-week uncomplicated breech pregnancy would be to attempt an External Cephalic Version (ECV) followed by a trial of vaginal delivery if successful. This approach provides an opportunity to avoid surgery and promotes natural birth, assuming the ECV is successful and there are no other contraindications for vaginal delivery.

choices.text: Internalization and degradation of ferroportin is done by hepcidin
Hepcidin plays an important role of regulation of iron absorption and distribution

questions.text: Fact about hepcidin is?
questions.solution:
• Iron absorption itself is controlled by level of iron in the body.
  • Hepcidin is an iron regulating hormone.(Option C)
  • Hepcidin causes internalization and degradation of ferroportin. Thus causes decreasing the iron transfer into the blood plasma from the duodenum.(Option A)
  • The hepcidin level is regulated by feedback of iron concentration in the plasma and liver.(Option B)
  • Release of iron from macrophages is due to ferroportin.

questions.text: A 58 year old female presents with a swelling located at the semilunar line just below the level of the umbilicus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spigelian Hernia

  • A rare abdominal wall hernia occurring along the Spigelian fascia, between the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle and the semilunar line.
  • Location: Typically occurs in the lower abdomen below the umbilicus, lateral to the rectus sheath.
  • Epidemiology: More common in middle-aged and elderly individuals; slight female predominance.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical examination may be difficult due to the deep location; Ultrasound or CT scan is the imaging modality of choice for confirmation.
  • Complications: Incarceration and strangulation are common, due to the narrow neck of the hernia sac.
  • Treatment: Surgical repair

Explanation of Options:

Inguinal hernia (Option A):Inguinal hernias are located in the groin, not at the semilunar line.

Umbilical hernia (Option B):Umbilical hernias are located at the umbilicus, not below it.

Femoral hernia (Option D):Femoral hernias occur below the inguinal ligament.

Key points:

  • Occurs along the semilunar line, commonly below the level of the umbilicus.
  • Difficult to diagnose on clinical examination and often requires imaging.

questions.solution:

Type 1 (Option A): Type 1 tumours are located > 1 cm above GEJ Upto 5 cm.

Type 3 (Option C): Type 3 Tumours are located > 2 cm below GEJ Upto 5 cm.

Type 4 (Option D): Type 4 Doesn't exist.

Key Takeaway:

Siewert Classification:

questions.text: Identify the type of pelvis shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Naegele's pelvis (Option D) is a type of oblique pelvis where one ala (wing) of the sacrum is absent or underdeveloped. This leads to asymmetry in the pelvis, which can cause difficulty during childbirth due to the altered shape of the pelvic inlet. This deformity specifically matches the description of the condition where one ala of the sacrum is absent.


Robert's pelvis (Option A) is characterized by the presence of two pubic bones with both sides alae of sacrum being absent.


Scoliotic pelvis (Option B) results from a spinal curvature condition known as scoliosis, leading to asymmetry of the pelvis but not specifically involving the sacral ala. The pelvis is often tilted or distorted due to the abnormal spinal curvature, but the sacral anatomy, such as the alae, is typically intact.

Rachitic pelvis (Option C) is caused by rickets, a disease resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to softening and weakening of the bones, including pelvic bones. The pelvis is deformed with a flattened appearance, but there is no characteristic absence of one sacral ala as seen in Naegele's pelvis.

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/

choices.text: Stimulation of O2 sensitive K+ channels
Stimulation of ATP sensitive K+ channels
Inhibition of ligand gated calcium channels

questions.text: In response to hypoxia in systemic arteries there is vasodilatation. Which of the following channels primarily are responsible for vasodilation?
questions.solution:
• ATP-sensitive potassium channelsare crucial in the vasodilatory response to hypoxia.
  • When oxygen levels are low, the decrease in ATP productionleads to the opening of these channels. The opening of K+ATP channels allows potassium to efflux, causing hyper-polarization of the smooth muscle cell membrane. This hyper-polarization reduces the activity of voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to a decrease in intracellular calcium levels, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
  • Stimulation of O2 sensitive K+ channels (Option A) - O2-sensitive potassium channelsare found in certain tissues like the carotid body, where they play a role in sensing oxygen levels.
  • In hypoxic conditions, This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ influx,primarily via L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. It causes vasoconstriction in pulmonary vessels.
  • Inhibition of ligand gated calcium channels (Option C) - Ligand-gated calcium channelsare typically involved in responses triggered by specific ligands (such as neurotransmitters) binding to their receptors. It may cause vasodilatation but the primary mechanism is K+ channels.
  • Na+ K+ ATPase pump activity (Option D)- The Na+ K+ ATPase pumpis crucial for maintaining the electrochemical gradient across cell membranes by pumping sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell using ATP.

questions.text: Bartholin's gland in females is homologous to which of the following in males:
questions.solution:
Cowper's glands, also known as bulbourethral glands in males, are the homologous structures to Bartholin's glands in females. Both glands are responsible for secreting mucus that lubricates the respective areas: Cowper's glands secrete into the urethra, while Bartholin's glands secrete into the vaginal orifice.

The table below mentions all the homologous structures of male and female reproductive system and their origin.


Cowper's glands, also known as bulbourethral glands in males, are the homologous structures to Bartholin's glands in females. Both glands are responsible for secreting mucus that lubricates the respective areas: Cowper's glands secrete into the urethra, while Bartholin's glands secrete into the vaginal orifice.

Glands of Littre (Option A) are mucus-secreting glands located along the male urethra. They are not directly related to the female reproductive system and have no homologous structure with Bartholin's gland.

Skene's glands (Option C) also known as the paraurethral glands, are located near the female urethra and are homologous to the prostate gland in males, not to the Bartholin's glands.

Prostate (Option D) is a male accessory sex gland that contributes to semen production. The homologous structure in females would be Skene's glands, not Bartholin's glands.

questions.text: Examine the image below showing a blood smear. What is the most likely parasite shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows schizonts, which are characteristic of Plasmodium vivax, a common cause of malaria.

Plasmodium vivax is one of the five species of malaria parasites that infect humans. It is responsible for vivax malaria, which is generally less severe than Plasmodium falciparum malaria but can still lead to significant morbidity due to its relapsing nature.

Life Cycle:

  • After a mosquito bite, sporozoites enter the bloodstream and infect liver cells, where they develop into hypnozoites(dormant forms) or continue as merozoites that invade red blood cells.
  • Hypnozoites can remain dormant in the liver for months or years and reactivate to cause relapses of malaria.

Clinical Features:

  • Causes tertian malaria, where fevers recur every 48 hours.
  • Symptoms include fever, chills, sweating, headache, nausea, and fatigue.
  • Can lead to severe anemia due to the parasite's invasion of red blood cells.
  • Relapses are common due to reactivation of hypnozoites from the liver.

Gametocytes:

  • Unlike P. falciparum, Plasmodium vivax gametocytes are round in shape, not banana-shaped.

Babesia microti (Option A): This parasite causes babesiosis and can be identified by the presence of ring forms, but often lacks the specific multi-ring forms or schizonts seen in the image.


Trypanosoma brucei (Option B): Causes African sleeping sickness and is usually found in blood as trypomastigotes, not ring forms inside red blood cells.

Leishmania braziliensis (Option D): Typically found in tissue samples or bone marrow smears, not in blood smears.


Key Takeaway: Plasmodium vivax is identified by ring forms and schizonts within red blood cells, which are specific to malaria diagnosis.

Reference: For further details on Plasmodium vivax and its blood smear identification, see the CDC's malaria resources: CDC - Malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not attached to the cornua of uterus?
questions.solution:
Infundibulopelvic ligament, also known as the suspensory ligament of the ovary, connects the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall and carries the ovarian vessels. It does not attach to the cornua of the uterus but rather to the ovary and lateral pelvic wall, which is why it is the correct answer

Round ligament (Option A): Attaches at the uterine cornua and extends through the inguinal canal to the labia majora; it maintains uterine anteversion .

Fallopian tube (Option C): Directly arises from the uterine cornua and conducts ova from the ovary to the uterus .

Ovarian ligament (Option D): Connects the ovary to the cornua of the uterus just below the fallopian tube insertion .


Fig: Structure attached to cornua of uterus

Key takeaway: Mnemonic to remember the structures attached to the cornua of the uterus from anterior to posterior aspect using "RTO":

RTO:

  • R - Round ligament
  • T - Tube (Fallopian tube)
  • O - Ovarian ligament

questions.text: Examine the image of the electron microscope view provided. Which virus is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Influenza Virus

Shape:

  • Typically spherical or oval, with a diameter of about 80-120 nm.
  • Some strains can be pleomorphic, meaning they may vary in shape, occasionally forming filamentous structures.

Envelope:

  • The virus is enveloped, meaning it has a lipid membrane derived from the host cell.
  • Embedded in the envelope are two key surface proteins:
    • Hemagglutinin (HA): Responsible for binding to host cell receptors.
    • Neuraminidase (NA): Helps the virus to release from the host cell after replication.

Core:

  • Inside the envelope is the viral genome, made up of 8 segments of single-stranded RNA, which are associated with nucleoproteins and packaged in a helical configuration.

Surface:

  • The surface of the virus is studded with the HA and NA spikes, which give the virus its characteristic appearance and are crucial for its infectivity.

HIV (Option A): HIV particles are spherical but have a more irregular shape and are covered with a dense layer of glycoprotein spikes, which is different from the spiked structure seen in the image.


HBV (Option B): Hepatitis B virus is more spherical with a less pronounced spiked appearance and has a more complex surface structure.


HSV (Option D): Herpes Simplex Virus is known for its icosahedral capsid structure and does not typically exhibit the spiked envelope seen in the image.

Key Takeaway: The Influenza Virus is characterized by its spherical shape with a spiked envelope. Identifying these spikes helps in distinguishing it from other viruses.

Reference: For more information on the Influenza Virus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Influenza (Flu).

questions.text: Peg cells are found in
questions.solution:
Peg cells are a component of the epithelial lining of the fallopian tubes, where they play a crucial role in reproductive physiology. They are specialized secretory cells that produce a fluid that nourishes and supports the egg and sperm during their journey through the fallopian tube. This fluid also helps in the transport of the egg and facilitates fertilization.



Fig: Histology of Fallopian tube

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient with a history of food poisoning presented to the emergency department with multiple episodes of vomiting, mild diarrhoea and weakness. He was given an intravenous drug to control the severity of vomiting and later he developed abnormal posture as given in the image below. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
A central anticholinergic like benzhexol is the first-line treatment for acute dystonia (e.g., torticollis from metoclopramide), typically resolving symptoms within minutes to hours.

Acute muscular dystonia:

  • Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles -grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most during treatment with Dopaminergic antagonist therapy.
  • Here mostly Metoclopramide is given as an anti-emetic drug and as it is dopaminergic antagonist it has created acute dystonia as side effect.
  • One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Central anticholinergics :

  • The central anticholinergics act by reducing the unbalanced cholinergic activity in the striatum of parkinsonian patients.
  • Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug (phenothiazines, other D2 antagonists) induced parkinsonism.

Levodopa (Option A): Levodopa-a dopamine prodrug-is not effective in acute muscular dystonia; it's primarily beneficial in dopa-responsive dystonia (a genetic/childhood condition), not in standard muscular dystonia

Ondansetron (Option C): As a 5-HT3 antagonist antiemetic, ondansetron is not effective for muscular dystonia-and in fact has been reported to cause acute dystonic reactions in some cases

Selegiline (Option D): Selegiline, an MAO-B inhibitor that reduces monoamine metabolism, is not effective in treating acute muscular dystonia-anticholinergics like benztropine or diphenhydramine, and sometimes benzodiazepines, are the treatments of choice .

Key Takeaway:

Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug induced parkinsonism.

questions.text: Most common site for adenocarcinoma of cervix is:
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma most commonly originates from the glandular (mucin-producing) columnar epithelium in the endocervix, i.e., the cervical canal. These glandular cells produce mucus, and this region is the primary site for cervical adenocarcinoma

Transformation zone (Option A): Incorrect for adenocarcinoma. This area-where squamous metaplastic epithelium meets columnar epithelium-is the most frequent origin for squamous cell carcinoma, not adenocarcinoma .

Ectocervix (Option B): Covered by squamous epithelium, not glandular cells. It is not the common site for adenocarcinoma .

Equal incidence at all sites (Option D): Incorrect-adenocarcinoma predominantly arises from the endocervical glandular cells, not equally across cervix

questions.text: Look at the image of the virus particle. What virus is shown?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus has an icosahedral shape, which means it is a symmetrical, 20-sided structure. The virus is non-enveloped and its capsid is made up of 252 protein subunits called capsomeres, arranged in an icosahedron.

Each vertex of the icosahedron has a fiber-like projection, called a penton, which helps the virus attach to and infect host cells.

HSV (Option A) : Herpes Simplex Virus has an enveloped structure with an icosahedral capsid inside, but it is enveloped, not naked like the virus shown.

Papillomavirus (Option B): Papillomavirus is also icosahedral but is smaller and lacks the complex protein shell seen here.

HPV (Option D): Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is similar to Papillomavirus, with a simpler structure compared to the image shown.

Key Takeaway: Adenovirus is characterized by its icosahedral shape with a complex protein shell, which is crucial for identifying it.

Reference: For more information on Adenovirus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Adenovirus.

questions.text: A Chronic Alcoholic Patient presented with Grade I Fatty liver & High Triglyceride levels in blood. Metabolic derangement in this patient include
questions.solution:
Alcohol Metabolism in our body requires enzyme Alcohol Dehydrogenase which is Metalloenzymes and Zn is an essential component of Enzyme. Examples of other Metalloenzymes includes Carboxypeptidase A, Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitor, Adenosine Deaminase, Alkaline Phosphatase, Phospholipase C, Leucine Aminopeptidase, The Cytosolic Form of Superoxide Dismutase.

Ethanol metabolism ↑ NADH/ NAD+ ratio in liver, causing:

  1. Lactic acidosis - ↑ pyruvate conversion to lactate
  2. Fasting hypoglycemia - ↓ gluconeogenesis due to ↑ conversion of OAA to malate
  3. Ketoacidosis - diversion of acetyl-CoA into ketogenesis rather than TCA cycle
  4. Hepatosteatosis - ↑ conversion of DHAP to glycerol-3-P
    • 4A ; acetyl-CoA diverges into fatty acid synthesis
    • 4B , which combines with glycerol-3-P to synthesize triglycerides

Change & Increase in in NAD / NADH ratio (Option A) Oxidation of Ethanol by Alcohol Dehydrogenase leading to increase production of NADH which will increase NADH/NAD+ ratio & production of Acetaldehyde. Acetaldehyde is a toxic metabolite which needs to be converted into non toxic substance with Aldehyde Dehydrogenase enzyme.

Decrease in S. Lactate level will lead to Increase in Uric Acid Stone (Option C) Increased (NADH)/(NAD+) ratio causes increased (lactate)/(pyruvate), resulting in hyper lactic acidemia, which decreases excretion of uric acid, aggravating gout. (S. Lactate levels are increased).

Excess Intake of Alcohol Promotes Fatty Acid Oxidation (Option D) Alteration of NADH / NAD ratio, will leads to inhibition of Fatty Acid Oxidation and esterification of Fatty acid to Triacyl glyceride.

choices.text: Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides): Characterized by its large, cylindrical shape and smooth surface
Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus): Identified by its hook-like anterior end and the presence of cutting plates or teeth
Strongyloides (Strongyloides stercoralis): Known for its small size and the presence of rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity
Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura): Recognizable by its thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end

questions.text:
Identify the Parasite from the Image
The image below displays a microscopic view of a parasitic worm. Based on the visible features, which of the following correctly identifies the parasite shown?
questions.solution:
Ancylostoma duodenale (Hookworm) features a hook-like anterior end and may have cutting plates or teeth. It has segmented eggs with blastomeres.


Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) is large, cylindrical, and smooth, which does not match the hook-like appearance shown in the image.(Option A)


Strongyloides stercoralis (Strongyloides) is smaller and characterized by rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity, unlike the hook-like structure.(Option C)


Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) has a thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end and barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs.(Option D)


Key Takeaway: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) can be identified by their segmented appearance with blastomeres. This distinguishes them from other parasitic worms based on morphological features.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hookworm. CDC Hookworm

questions.text: A 28 year old man is brought to the emergency room after being found unconscious. He opens his eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and withdraws from pain. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
The GCS score is calculated as follows: Eye Opening (E2), Verbal Response (V2), and Motor Response (M4) =8

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

  • Eye Opening (E):
    • E4: Spontaneous
    • E3: To speech
    • E2: To pain
    • E1: None
  • Verbal Response (V):
    • V5: Oriented
    • V4: Confused
    • V3: Inappropriate words
    • V2: Incomprehensible sounds
    • V1: None
  • Motor Response (M):
    • M6: Obeys commands
    • M5: Localizes pain
    • M4: Withdraws from pain
    • M3: Flexion (decorticate posture)
    • M2: Extension (decerebrate posture)
    • M1: None

Key Takeaways:

  • GCS 8 indicates severe brain injury, often requiring immediate medical intervention.
  • GCS is essential for assessing consciousness and determining the need for further neurological evaluation.

choices.text: Type I Mirizzi's syndrome; laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Type II Mirizzi's syndrome; ERCP with stent placement
Type III Mirizzi's syndrome; open cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration
Type IV Mirizzi's syndrome; liver resection

questions.text: A 65 year old patient presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and fever. Imaging reveals a large gallstone impacted in the cystic duct, common bile duct with large fistula formation. Which classification and treatment option are most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Type III involves a large fistula and partial cholecystobiliary fistula, requiring open surgery for safe management.

Mirizzi's Syndrome - Classification and Treatment

  • Gallstone impaction in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing common hepatic duct compression.
  • Classification:
    • Type I: External compression without fistula.
    • Type II: Small cholecystobiliary fistula.
    • Type III: Large cholecystobiliary fistula (>2 cm).
    • Type IV: Complete destruction of the common bile duct wall.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, fever.
    • May present with cholangitis.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging: Ultrasound, MRCP, or ERCP shows gallstone and ductal compression.
    • ERCP: Confirms fistula presence and location.
  • Management:
    • Type I: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
    • Type II-IV: Open cholecystectomy, bile duct exploration, and repair. May require biliary drainage procedures.

Explanation of Options:

Observation and follow-up imaging (Option A): Incorrect. Type I Mirizzi involves only external compression and can be managed laparoscopically, but this case involves a fistula.

ERCP with stent placement (Option B): Incorrect. Although ERCP helps with diagnosis or temporary decompression, fistula cases typically need surgical repair.

Liver resection (Option D): Incorrect. Liver resection is not part of standard treatment for Mirizzi syndrome.

Key Points:

  • Mirizzi's syndrome involves cystic duct gallstones compressing the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: A 40 year old male visited to hospital with complaint of difficulty in lifting his left arm above head. He had lifted a heavy table a few days ago. On examination, his left scapular border became prominent, when asked to push against the wall. Which of the following nerve is most likely to damage?
questions.solution:
Long thoracic nerve: That supply serratus anterior muscle. It cause over head abduction and protraction of scapula. So damage to long thoracic nerve lead to paralysis of serratus anterior muscle. The condition is called winging of scapula.

Winged scapula

Option wise explanation:

Axillary nerve (Option B): Innervates the deltoid muscle, the primary abductor of the shoulder, enabling arm elevation up to 90°. Damage to the axillary nerve leads to impaired abduction and deltoid atrophy. This makes it essential for lifting the arm above the head.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Innervates the flexor carpi ulnaris and intrinsic hand muscles; not involved in shoulder abduction.

Thoracodorsal nerve (Option D): Supplies latissimus dorsi, which adducts, extends, and medially rotates the arm-not for lifting above the head.

Type II choledochal cyst; cyst aspiration

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a cystic dilation of the common bile duct. What is the most appropriate classification and treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and imaging reveals a Type I choledochal cyst which is managed by cyst excision and hepaticojejunostomy

Choledochal Cyst : Todani Classification and Treatment


  1. Type I:
    • Fusiform dilation of the CBD.
    • Most common type.
    • Treatment: Excision and hepaticojejunostomy.
  2. Type II:
    • CBD diverticulum.
    • Treatment: Excision of the diverticulum.
  3. Type III:
    • Choledochocele, dilation at the duodenum.
    • Treatment: Endoscopic sphincterotomy.
  4. Type IV:
    • Multiple cysts, both intrahepatic and extrahepatic.
    • Treatment: Cyst excision and biliary reconstruction.
  5. Type V:
    • Caroli's disease (intrahepatic cysts).
    • Treatment: Varies, may include liver transplant in severe cases.

Key Points:

  • Choledochal cysts present with jaundice, pain, and mass.
