questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever with chills. Physical examination shows hypotension and confusion. What do these findings suggest?
questions.solution:
Charcot's triad (fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain) plus hypotension and confusion (Reynold's pentad) indicate acute cholangitis with sepsis.

Charcot's Triad and Reynold's Pentad

  1. Charcot's Triad:
    • Right upper quadrant pain, fever with chills, jaundice.
    • Classic sign of acute cholangitis.
  2. Reynold's Pentad:
    • Charcot's triad plus hypotension and altered mental status.
    • Indicates severe cholangitis with systemic sepsis.
  3. Clinical Significance:
    • Suggests biliary tract infection, often due to bile duct obstruction.Can lead to septic shock if untreated.

Explanation of Options:

  • Acute pancreatitis (Option A): Acute pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back but does not typically cause jaundice or fever.
  • Biliary colic (Option B): Biliary colic involves intermittent pain without systemic signs like fever or hypotension.
  • Gallstone ileus (Option D): This condition causes intestinal obstruction, not jaundice and fever.

Key Points:

Charcot's triad indicates acute cholangitis; Reynold's pentad suggests severe sepsis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old boy with hemoglobin SS disease for routine health care in your primary care practice. His mother is 7 months pregnant with the couple's second child. They know that there is a risk that the newborn will also have sickle cell disease, but they declined prenatal diagnostic procedures because of the risk to the fetus. They ask how soon after birth the diagnosis of sickle cell disease can be made. Of the following, the MOST appropriate answer to their question is
questions.solution:
• Newborns have a predominance of hemoglobin F (fetal hemoglobin, α2γ2) at birth and a minor expression of hemoglobin A (adult hemoglobin, α2β2).
  • Abnormal hemoglobin can be detected from a neonatal blood spot; thus, sickle cell disease can be diagnosed in the newborn.
  • Newborn screening results are reported as FA for newborns with normal hemoglobin, FS for newborns with hemoglobin SS disease, and FAS for newborns with sickle cell trait.

questions.solution:

Mesentery:

It is a broad, fan shaped fold of peritoneum which suspends the coils of jejunum and ileum from the posterior abdominal wall.

Option wise explanation:

questions.text: A 60 year old woman undergoing imaging for unrelated abdominal pain is found to have calcification of the gallbladder wall. She denies any symptoms of gallbladder disease. What is the appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Porcelain gallbladder is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall, often due to chronic inflammation from gallstones. The potential severity of gallbladder cancer justifies prophylactic cholecystectomy. The procedure is recommended even in asymptomatic patients to prevent malignancy

Porcelain Gallbladder

  • Gallbladder wall calcification.
  • Etiology: Chronic inflammation from gallstones leading to calcification.
  • Clinical Presentation: Often asymptomatic.May be found incidentally on imaging.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Detected on abdominal Xray, CT scan, or ultrasound as calcified gallbladder.
  • Management:
    • Elective cholecystectomy due to increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma.

Observation and follow-up imaging (Option A): Not routinely recommended for asymptomatic patients with porcelain gallbladder. While some studies suggest low malignancy risk, prophylactic cholecystectomy is often preferred to mitigate potential cancer risk.

Percutaneous drainage (Option C): Indicated for patients with cholecystitis who are poor surgical candidates. Not appropriate for asymptomatic porcelain gallbladder without infection or abscess.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) (Option D): Not suitable for porcelain gallbladder without biliary obstruction or pancreatitis. ERCP is primarily used for managing bile duct stones or strictures.

Key Points:

  • Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a higher risk of cancer.

questions.text: A 5-day-old, full-term male infant was severely cyanotic at birth. Prostaglandin E was administered initially and later ballooned atrial septostomy was done which showed improvement in oxygenation. The most likely diagnosis of this infant is
questions.solution:
• Cyanosis at birth, PGE infusion and atrial septostomy to improve oxygen are typical of TGA.
  • In complete transposition of great vessels, there are independent systemic and pulmonary circulation with communication only through ductus arteriosus. Hence, patency of ductus arteriosus is to be maintained to ensure mixing of blood. Due to deoxygenated blood flowing in the systemic circulation, moderate to severe cyanosis is present at birth.
  • As a part of rescue therapy initially, atrial septostomy to ensure mixing of blood.
  • Atrial septostomy is not done in other options mentioned.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with cyclical mastalgia that has been worsening over the past few months, especially just before her periods. She has no palpable lumps on breast examination and her imaging studies are normal. What is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Most cases of cyclical mastalgia are benign, and reassurance along with lifestyle changes such as reducing caffeine and using supportive bras is recommended.

Mastalgia

  • Cyclical Mastalgia:
    • Pain related to the menstrual cycle, generally starting mid-cycle and increasing in severity until menstruation. Both breasts are usually involved.
    • Hormonal sensitivity, possibly due to estrogen.
  • Non-Cyclical Mastalgia:
    • Unrelated to the menstrual cycle, localized to a specific region of the breast. Causes include duct ectasia, trauma, and musculoskeletal pain.
    • causes:Trauma, infections, musculoskeletal causes (e.g., Tietze's syndrome), and occasionally malignancy
  • Management:
    • First-line: Reassurance, lifestyle modifications, supportive bras, and reducing caffeine intake.
    • Medical Treatment: Tamoxifen 10 mg or Danazol 50-300 mg for severe cases.
    • Topical NSAIDs: For localized breast pain, topical diclofenac or piroxicam may be used.

Oral contraceptives (Option A): Oral contraceptives are not the first-line treatment for mastalgia, particularly cyclical mastalgia.

Tamoxifen 10 mg daily (Option B): Tamoxifen is used for severe cases of mastalgia but not as the first-line treatment.

Immediate biopsy (Option D): Mastalgia without concerning features on examination or imaging does not require a biopsy.

Key Points:

  • Cyclical mastalgia responds well to reassurance and lifestyle modifications. Severe cases may require treatment with tamoxifen or danazol.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is having uncontrolled diabetes with HbA1c value 9.8% & not on regular treatment. All the following enzymes is inhibited except
questions.solution:
Uncontrolled diabetes with a high HbA1c value (9.8%) is a state of fasting state (insulin deficient state ), Various catabolic metabolic Pathway related to Carbohydrate, lipid and Protein Metabolism is activated due to decreased insulin Action.

Hormone-sensitive lipase is the one enzyme not inhibited in uncontrolled diabetes-low insulin levels mean HSL remains active, promoting lipolysis-whereas glycogen synthase, PFK-1, and lipoprotein lipase are all downregulated when insulin is deficient

  • Lipoprotein lipase involved in Hydrolysis of Triglycerides in Lipoprotein into free fatty acid and Glycerol.
  • Glycogen Synthase: Insulin induce the action of Glycogen Synthase. In uncontrolled diabetes In diabetes, particularly with high blood glucose levels, glycogen synthase activity is typically decreased.
  • Insulin normally activates glycogen synthase to promote glycogen synthesis, but in uncontrolled diabetes, this activation is impaired.
  • Phosphofructokinase I (PFK-1): Enzyme is activated by Insulin In uncontrolled diabetes, where insulin action is impaired, PFK-1 activity is reduced due to decreased insulin levels or resistance.

questions.text: A healthy term baby girl is born via elective cesarean delivery due to breech presentation. On physical exam, when abducting and rotating the infant's legs you hear a "clunk" on the left hip. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for suspected developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in infants under 4-6 months-especially with a positive Ortolani clunk and high-risk factors like breech presentation-because the femoral head is still cartilaginous and invisible on X-ray

  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is a condition at birth in which the femoral head and the acetabulum are misaligned or grow abnormally.
  • If not detected early, the hip joint will grow abnormally resulting in degenerative joint disease, impaired walking, chronic pain, or permanent disability.
  • Currently, the guidelines for screening are serial physical examinations up to one year of age using the Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers and ultrasonography.
  • The Barlow exam is done by adducting a flexed hip, and the Ortolani is performed by abducting a flexed hip. Both exams are done to identify a dislocatable hip.
  • A positive Ortolani or Barlow indicates the need for further investigation with ultrasonography.
  • Treatment of DDH varies depending on the age of discovery and severity.
  • The Pavlik method is a common nonsurgical method that positions the baby's hip in a way that the joints align and the baby can grow normally.
  • Surgical interventions are reserved for more severe cases, late diagnosis, or failed nonsurgical treatment.

X-ray of both hips (Option D) - Not useful in newborns since the femoral head is cartilaginous until ~4-months, making X-rays insensitive early on .

MRI of both hips (Option A) - Unnecessary and impractical as first-line imaging; ultrasound is non-invasive, readily available, and sufficient unless complex pathology is suspected.

Observation (Option B) - Risky; a true Ortolani clunk indicates instability that needs imaging and possible early treatment-watchful waiting isn't recommended in this scenario

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain and fever. She is diagnosed with red degeneration of a fibroid. What is the most likely pathophysiological process involved?
questions.solution:
Red degeneration is due to necrosis of the fibroid tissue caused by compromised blood supply, leading to hemorrhagic infarction.

Red degeneration, also known as caseous degeneration, occurs when a fibroid undergoes necrosis due to reduced or compromised blood supply. During pregnancy,fibroids can grow rapidly and outstrip their blood supply, leading to hemorrhage and necrosis, which results in the characteristic pain and fever.There is leukocytosis and raised ESR.(Differentiated from torsion of fibroid where WBC count and ESR is normal).

Infection of the fibroid (Option A): Infection of a fibroid, while it can occur, is not typically associated with red degeneration. Red degeneration is more related to the changes in the fibroid's blood supply rather than an infection.

Malignant transformation (Option C): While fibroids can sometimes undergo malignant transformation, this is rare and not typically associated with red degeneration. Red degeneration is related to changes in blood supply rather than malignancy.

Calcification of the fibroid (option D): Calcification of fibroids usually occurs over a longer period and is not associated with acute symptoms like severe pain and fever. It is a late change rather than an acute one.

Note: The most common degeneration in fibroid is hyaline degeneration whereas the least common is malignancy.

choices.text: No further action required if asymptomatic

questions.text: A 55-year-old female undergoes a mammogram as part of her routine screening. The report indicates a BI-RADS 4b category lesion. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
BI-RADS 4 lesions indicate a moderate to high suspicion of malignancy, particularly 4b (10-50% malignancy risk), necessitating biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

BI-RADS Score

Key Points:

  • BI-RADS 3: Short-term follow-up.
  • BI-RADS 4-6: Requires biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

Routine annual screening (Option A) - BI-RADS 4 lesions suggest suspicion for malignancy, and follow-up with just annual screening would not be appropriate.

Follow-up imaging in 6 months (Option C) - This option is appropriate for BI-RADS 3, which indicates "probably benign" findings.

No further action required if asymptomatic (Option D) - Action must be taken based on radiological findings, not just the presence or absence of symptoms.

questions.text: Below diagram shows the potential occurring in the pacemaker of the heart. The marked phase is depolarization phase in the potential. It occurs due to which type of channels from the following?
questions.solution:
The Ca2+ current (ICa) due to opening of L channels causes the depolarization.

The potential generated by the pacemakers in the heart (SA node, primarily) is known as pacemaker potential.

Occurs in the SA and AV nodes:

  • Phase 0 = upstroke-opening of voltage-gated L type Ca2+
  • Phases 1 and 2 are absent in pacemaker potential.
  • Phase 3 = repolarization-inactivation of the Ca2+ channels and ↑ activation of K+ channels ↑↑ K+ efflux
  • Phase 4 = slow spontaneous diastolic depolarization due to If ("funny current") and T type ca2+ If (funny current) channels responsible for a slow, mixed Na+ inward/K+ outward current.
  • The slope of phase 4 in the SA node determines HR (heart rate)
    1. ACh/adenosine ↓ the rate of diastolic depolarization and ↓ HR,
    2. catecholamines ↑ depolarization and ↑ HR

Image of Pacemaker potential:

  • F Channel (Option A) & Na+ channel (Option D): The Na+ and K+ channels activated following hyperpolarization. They are leaky channels and referred to as "If" channels. Because of this funny activation these channels are known as "f" channels.
  • T calcium channel (Option C): The Ca2+ current (ICa) due to opening of T channels completes the prepotential.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in a reproductive-aged woman?
questions.solution:
Uterine fibroids, or leiomyomas, are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in reproductive-aged women. They can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged periods, or bleeding between periods.

Fig: FIGO classification of AUB.

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) (Option B): PCOS is a common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in reproductive-aged women due to hormonal imbalances that can lead to irregular or absent menstrual periods.

Endometrial cancer (Option A): While endometrial cancer can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, it is relatively rare compared to other causes, especially in premenopausal women.

Endometritis (Option D): Endometritis, an infection or inflammation of the endometrium, can cause abnormal bleeding, but it is less common compared to uterine fibroids in reproductive-aged women.

questions.text: HMG (Human Menopausal Gonadotropin) is a combination of:
questions.solution:
HMG is a medication that contains a combination of Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH). These hormones are derived from the urine of postmenopausal women and are used to stimulate ovarian follicle development and maturation in fertility treatments.

FSH + HCG (Option B): Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (HCG) is often used in combination with FSH for ovulation induction, but it is not part of the HMG formulation. HCG is used to trigger ovulation after follicle development has been stimulated by FSH.

LH + HCG (Option C): HMG does not contain HCG. HCG is used separately, typically after follicle stimulation with FSH and LH.

FSH + GnRH (Option D): Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is a different type of hormone that stimulates the release of FSH and LH from the pituitary gland. It is not included in the composition of HMG.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism the body uses to reduce core temperature when it becomes too high?
questions.solution:
Sweating is the body's primary mechanism for reducing core temperature. When sweat evaporates from the skin, it removes heat from the body, effectively cooling it down.

  • Vasoconstriction(Option B) - Vasoconstriction helps conserve heat by reducing blood flow to the skin.
  • Shivering (Option C) - Shivering generates heat by causing muscle contractions, which is a response to cold temperatures,
  • Increased metabolic rate (Option D) - Increased metabolic rate would generate more heat, not reduce it.

Involvement of the mucosa (Option A): Tumour limited to Mucosa only is early gastric carcinoma

Involvement of mucosa and submucosa (Option B): Tumour limited to Mucosa & Submucosa is Early Gastric Carcinoma.

Involvement of the mucosa and submucosa with its lymphatic involvement (Option D): Lymph Node Involvement doesn't Upstage Gastric carcinoma. ( Muscularis Propia Involvement does )

Key Takeaway:

Early gastric cancer is defined as cancer limited to the mucosa and submucosa with or without lymph node involvement.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male infant from a family with a known history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2B (MEN 2B) has tested positive for a specific RET mutation associated with the syndrome. There is no evidence of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) on imaging, and his calcitonin levels are mildly elevated. What is the recommended next step in managing this infant?
questions.solution:
In MEN 2B patients, prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended within the first year of life due to the high risk of early-onset MTC.

MEN Type 2A and 2B

  • MEN 2A: Associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.
  • MEN 2B: Associated with MTC, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas, but no parathyroid disease.

RET Mutation: A genetic mutation in the RET proto-oncogene leads to the development of MEN 2 syndromes.

Surgery in MEN 2B:

  • Timing: Prophylactic thyroidectomy should be performed as soon as possible within the first year of life to prevent the development of MTC.
  • Screening: Calcitonin levels are monitored to detect early C-cell hyperplasia, but surgery is recommended before any cancer is detectable.

Surgery in MEN 2A:

  • Prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended before 5 years of age depending on the specific RET mutation. Genetic testing and family history are crucial in determining the timing.

Explanation Of Options:

Annual calcitonin screening until symptoms develop (Option A): Annual calcitonin screening alone is not sufficient for MEN 2B patients.

Wait until the child is 5 years old to consider thyroidectomy (Option C): Waiting until 5 years old increases the risk of MTC development in MEN 2B patients, making early surgery crucial.

Initiate chemotherapy for potential MTC (Option D): Chemotherapy is not indicated for prophylaxis in MEN 2B; surgery is the preventive measure for medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Key Points:

MEN 2B patients should undergo prophylactic thyroidectomy within the first year of life to prevent medullary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: Most dreaded adverse effect of clomiphene citrate when used for ovulation induction?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate, a SERM, predisposes to growth of multiple follicles and hence increases risk of a dreaded complication known as: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome(OHSS).Hence, Letrozole(Aromatase inhibitor),is currently the new drug for choice for ovulation induction as it predisposes to monofollicular development.

OHSS (Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome) is the most severe and dreaded adverse effect associated with clomiphene citrate. OHSS is characterized by enlarged ovaries, abdominal pain, ascites, and in severe cases, can lead to potentially life-threatening complications such as thromboembolism and respiratory distress. It results from excessive ovarian stimulation, making it the most significant risk associated with the medication.

Most important mediator of OHSS is VEGF.

Most important trigger for OHSS is Injection HCG.

Hot flushes(Option A) : This is a common but generally mild side effect of clomiphene citrate. It occurs due to the drug's effect on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis and is not considered a severe or life-threatening complication.

Visual disturbances (Option B): While visual disturbances can occur due to clomiphene citrate, they are usually transient and not the most severe outcome. The drug can affect the visual field temporarily, but these disturbances are not considered the most dreaded adverse effect.

Birth defects (Option D): While clomiphene citrate is generally considered safe, concerns about birth defects are not as significant compared to the risk of OHSS. Birth defects are not the most immediate or severe risk associated with this drug.

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of ligand gated channel?
questions.solution:
The Ryanodine receptor (RyR) (Option A) is an example of a ligand-gated channel. It is primarily found in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells, where it plays a crucial role in calcium release during muscle contraction.The RyR is activated by calcium induced calcium release (CICR) allowing calcium ions to flow out of the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm.

The Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) (Option B) is a voltage-gated calcium channel located in the T-tubules of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells.

Pressure receptor channels (Option C), such as those involved in mechano-transduction, are typically mechanosensitive channels.These channels open in response to mechanical forces such as pressure, stretch, or deformation of the cell membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most specific for diagnosing prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
MRI is the gold standard for diagnosing prolactinomas. It provides high-resolution images of the pituitary gland, allowing for precise identification and characterization of pituitary tumors, including their size and extent. MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting pituitary tumors and is essential for confirming the diagnosis of prolactinoma.

Serum prolactin levels (Option A): Elevated serum prolactin levels are suggestive of prolactinoma but are not specific. Hyperprolactinemia can result from other conditions such as hypothyroidism, medications (e.g., antipsychotics), and pituitary stalk compression. Therefore, while useful for initial screening, it does not confirm the diagnosis.

CT scan of the brain (Option B): CT scans can detect large pituitary tumors but lack the sensitivity and specificity of MRI. They are less effective in visualizing small microadenomas typical of prolactinomas and provide less detail of the pituitary gland and surrounding structures. MRI is preferred for detailed imaging of the pituitary region.

Serum TRH levels (Option D): Serum TRH levels are not relevant to the diagnosis of prolactinoma. TRH testing is more related to the assessment of the thyroid axis and is not used in the context of prolactinoma.

Key takeaway: MRI of the pituitary is the most specific and gold standard investigation for diagnosis of Prolactinoma because it directly visualizes the tumor, confirming its presence and distinguishing it from other potential causes of elevated prolactin levels.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with delayed puberty, anosmia, and low testosterone levels. Physical examination reveals a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kallmann syndrome features hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia due to failed migration of GnRH neurons and olfactory neurons-making loss of smell a distinguishing hallmark.

Klinefelter Syndrome (Option A): Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by hypogonadism, small testes, gynecomastia, tall stature, and elevated LH/FSH with low testosterone. It does not present with anosmia; patients usually retain a normal sense of smell.

Turner Syndrome (Option C): Turner syndrome affects females, causing short stature, ovarian dysgenesis, and lack of sexual development. It is not associated with anosmia or low testosterone in males.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (Option D): AIS involves 46, XY individuals with normal testosterone but androgen resistance, leading to female external genitalia and undescended testes. It is not accompanied by anosmia.

questions.text: Micro nutrient deficiency which leads to Menke's Syndrome is
questions.solution:
Menke's Syndrome, also known as Menke's kinky hair syndrome, is a x linked genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of copper due to a defect in copper transport.

Efflux of dietary Cu out of intestinal enterocytes into the circulation by a Cu transporting ATPase (ATP7A) is impaired.

This condition is characterized by

  • brittle, kinky hair,
  • growth failure, and
  • neurological symptoms.

Zn deficiency (Option A): Zinc deficiency results in acrodermatitis enteropathica, a malabsorption disorder that may present with vision issues such as photophobia or conjunctivitis.

Iron deficiency (Option C): Iron deficiency leads to iron deficiency anemia.

Magnesium deficiency (Option D): Magnesium deficiency causes hyper-excitability (tremors, muscle spasms) and cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: Most common cause of bilateral cornual block on HSG:
questions.solution:
Physiological spasm of the uterotubal junction during the procedure is the most common cause of bilateral cornual block on HSG. This spasm is transient and can be relieved with antispasmodic agents, showing normal tube patency on repeat HSG.

Gonococcal infection (Option A): Incorrect. While gonococcal PID can lead to tubal scarring and irregular dilation, it typically produces an ampullary or mid-tubal obstruction-not a cornual block on HSG.

Tuberculosis of the genital tract (Option B): Incorrect. Genital TB can cause bilateral tubal blockages, often with beading or clubbing and may occasionally result in cornual blocks. However, it usually presents with additional findings, such as endometrial calcifications or uterine synechiae, making it less likely as the most common cause.

Asherman's syndrome (Option D): Incorrect. Intrauterine adhesions seen in Asherman's syndrome affect the uterine cavity itself and may lead to proximal tubal entrance issues, but they primarily impact the uterine cavity-not isolated cornual tubal blocks as seen

questions.text: A child Presented with multiple fragile bone also known as Brittle Bone Disease. On Examination, Child has thin transparent sclera which appears blue. He had mutation in COLIA1 gene. Identify the most common inheritance of disorder from which a child is suffering.
questions.solution:
Child is suffering from Collagen vascular Disease - Osteogenesis Imperfecta.

Characteristic Symptoms and signs of disease includes

  • Multiple Fragile bones,
  • Joint Hypermobility and
  • Blue sclera

COLIA1 or COLIA2 Gene mutation. Most commonly it is autosomal dominant.

  • Types I to IV are caused by mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes or both.
  • Type I is mild, but type II is severe and infants born with the condition usually not survive,
  • Types III and IV are progressive and/or deforming.
  • Mutation results into replacement of Glycine affecting formation of Tripple Helix, decreased expression of Collagen, structurally abnormal, weakening of Bone, enzymatic Degradation called as Procollagen Suicide.

Collagen Vascular Diseases having Autosomal Dominant inheritance includes

  • Marfan's Syndrome,
  • Ehler Danlos Syndrome.

questions.text: Most common site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy:
questions.solution:
The ureter is most commonly injured at the point where it crosses under the uterine artery, which is often referred to as the "water under the bridge" location. This is because the ureter lies just beneath the uterine artery at the level of the cardinal ligament, making it vulnerable during dissection, clamping, or suturing in this area.

At the pelvic brim (Option A): Incorrect. The ureter does cross the pelvic brim over the iliac vessels during pelvic surgery, but this is not the most common site of injury during hysterectomy.

At the level of the uterosacral ligament (Option C): Incorrect. While the ureter runs adjacent to the uterosacral ligament, injuries here are less common; the primary danger zone is where it courses under the uterine artery.

Vesicoureteric junction (Option D): Incorrect. This distal location near the bladder is usually out of the operative field for a standard hysterectomy, unless extensive bladder dissection is being performed.

Key takeaway: Ureteral injury can also occur near other pelvic structures, but the crossing of the uterine artery is the most frequent site due to its close anatomical proximity to surgical maneuvers performed during hysterectomy.

Above figure shows the various points of constriction of the ureter and the probable points of injury.

Various points at which ureter is prone to injury in gynaecological surgery:

  1. At the pelvic brim, while clamping the ovarian vessels
  2. In the broad ligament while clamping the uterine vessels
  3. In the ureteric tunnel in cardinal ligament
  4. At the vault of the vagina before it enters the bladder

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents with a fluctuant non-tender swelling at the introitus. The attending Gynaecologist makes the diagnosis of a Bartholin's cyst. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Marsupialization is the preferred treatment for symptomatic or recurrent Bartholin's cysts. The procedure creates a permanent opening that facilitates continuous drainage and significantly reduces recurrence (2-13% recurrence rate).

Incision & Drainage (Option B): Incorrect. This method is typically used for acutely infected abscesses and provides only temporary relief. Without catheter placement or marsupialization, recurrence rates are high.

Aspiration (Option C): Incorrect. Simple needle aspiration is rarely used; it often leads to recurrence due to incomplete drainage and closure of the duct.

Surgical Resection (Option D): Incorrect. Complete gland excision is invasive and reserved for cases where other interventions have failed or when malignancy is suspected. It carries higher risks and is not first-line.

Key takeaway: Marsupialization offers a balance between effective, less invasive management and a lower recurrence rate, making it the best choice for symptomatic Bartholin's cyst.

choices.text: Referral to an ENT specialist for a throat biopsy
Administration of oral corticosteroids for inflammation

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sore throat, fever, and a grayish membrane observed on the back of the throat. The child has also been experiencing difficulty swallowing and breathing. The parents report that the child's immunizations are not up-to-date. Based on the clinical presentation and CDC guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is a potentially life-threatening bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, affecting the respiratory tract and sometimes the skin.


Pharyngeal or Tonsillar Diphtheria (Most Common Form):

  • Pseudomembrane:
    • Grayish-white or dirty-gray membrane forms on the tonsils, pharynx, or nasal passages.
    • Firmly adherent, and attempts to remove it may cause bleeding.
    • It can extend to the larynx, trachea, or bronchi, leading to airway obstruction.
    • Bull neck appearance: Severe cases may show lymphadenopathy and swelling of the neck due to regional inflammation.
    • Hoarseness and stridor: May develop as the disease progresses, indicating laryngeal involvement.
    • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing due to throat and neck swelling.
  • Cutaneous Diphtheria:
    • Chronic non-healing ulcers:
      • Infected wounds or skin lesions develop ulcers covered with a grayish membrane.
      • Most commonly seen in tropical regions or in people with poor hygiene.
    • Typically, less severe than respiratory diphtheria but still contagious.
  • Systemic Complications (Due to Toxin Spread):
    • Cardiac Complications:
      • Myocarditis: Can occur in the second or third week of illness.
        • Symptoms include arrhythmias, heart block, and heart failure.
        • Can lead to sudden death in severe cases.
  • Neurological Complications:
    • Cranial nerve palsies: Usually affects the soft palate, causing dysphonia(difficulty speaking) or dysphagia (difficulty swallowing).
    • Peripheral neuropathy: Occurs several weeks after the onset of diphtheria.
      • Involves motor weaknessor paralysis starting in the lower extremities, progressing in a pattern similar to Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Treatment:

The antitoxin is administered intravenously or intramuscularly as soon as the disease is suspected, without waiting for laboratory confirmation.

  • Perform a skin test before administration to rule out hypersensitivity to the antitoxin.

Dose: Depends on the severity and duration of the disease, ranging from 20,000 to 100,000 units.

First-line antibiotics:

  • Erythromycin: 40-50 mg/kg/day (maximum 2 g/day) for 14 days, orally or intravenously.
  • Penicillin G: 250,000 to 500,000 units intramuscularly every 6 hours for 14 days (alternatively, penicillin V can be used orally).

Immediate initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option A): Incorrect. While antibiotics such as penicillin or erythromycin are essential in diphtheria management, the critical first step-especially when a grayish pseudomembrane is present-is the administration of diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize circulating toxin. Antibiotics should follow to eradicate the bacteria and prevent spread.

Referral to an ENT specialist for a throat biopsy (Option C): Incorrect. Diagnosis of diphtheria is typically clinical and serological; biopsy is not part of initial management. Immediate treatment with antitoxin and antibiotics is vital; waiting for biopsy results can delay life-saving intervention.

Administration of oral corticosteroids for inflammation (Option D): Incorrect. Corticosteroids are not indicated in diphtheria treatment. The therapeutic focus should be on antitoxin to neutralize toxin and antibiotics (penicillin or erythromycin) to eliminate the organism.

Key Takeaway: The immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin is crucial in the management of diphtheria to neutralize the diphtheria toxin. Antibiotic therapy should follow to treat the bacterial infection.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Diphtheria Treatment Guidelines. CDC Diphtheria Treatment

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is taken for a health check-up as her parents feel she is too short. Her height is less than the 3rd centile and she has nonpitting edema of both lower limbs. Her blood pressure is 130/92mmHg in both upper limbs and a radio-femoral delay is noted on simultaneous palpation of pulses. What additional finding do you expect on general examination of this girl?
questions.solution:
• The patient in the scenario has short stature, hypertension, and findings consistent with bicuspid aortic valves and coarctation of the aorta.
  • Both bicuspid aortic valves and coarctation of the aorta are common among individuals with Turner syndrome.
  • Bicuspid aortic valves occur in up to 50% of patients with Turner syndrome while coarctation of aorta occurs in up to 20% of cases.
  • Physical findings in patients with Turner syndrome include nonpitting edema of the lower extremities, down slanting eyes, wide spaced nipples, and webbing of neck.

choices.text: The cholera toxin is a protease that degrades mucosal proteins, leading to fluid loss
The cholera toxin causes prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels and resulting in electrolyte and water secretion
The cholera toxin inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, resulting in decreased absorption of fluids
The cholera toxin disrupts the tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, leading to leakage of plasma into the intestinal lumen

questions.text: In the context of cholera, which of the following statements accurately describes the role of the cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of the disease?
questions.solution:
The cholera toxin binds to the Gs protein, leading to persistent activation of adenylate cyclase. This elevates intracellular cAMP, which causes intestinal epithelial cells to secrete large amounts of electrolytes and water, resulting in diarrhea.

  1. Binding: The B subunit of cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells.
  2. Entry: The toxin is internalized into the cell and transported to the endoplasmic reticulum.
  3. Activation: The A subunit is cleaved, and the A1 fragment enters the cytoplasm, acting as an enzyme.
  4. ADP-Ribosylation: A1 modifies the Gsα protein, leading to constant activation of adenylate cyclase.
  5. Increased cAMP: Adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), increasing intracellular cAMP levels.
  6. Chloride Secretion: cAMP activates CFTR chloride channels, causing secretion of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen.
  7. Water Loss: Sodium and water follow chloride into the lumen, resulting in massive fluid loss and watery diarrhea.

  • The cholera toxin is a protease that degrades mucosal proteins, leading to fluid loss (Option A): The cholera toxin is not a protease and does not degrade mucosal proteins. Its mechanism involves activation of cellular signaling pathways.
  • The cholera toxin inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, resulting in decreased absorption of fluids (Option C): The cholera toxin does not inhibit the sodium-potassium ATPase pump. Its effect on fluid secretion is mediated through increased intracellular cAMP levels.
  • The cholera toxin disrupts the tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, leading to leakage of plasma into the intestinal lumen (Option D): The cholera toxin does not primarily target tight junctions. Instead, it promotes fluid secretion via the adenylate cyclase-cAMP pathway.

Key Takeaway: The cholera toxin causes cholera by increasing intracellular cAMP levels through prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, which leads to excessive secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in severe diarrhea.

TIPS AND TRICKS - Bacteria that act by Camp - CALP

C-Cholera toxin

A-Anthrax

L-heat Labile toxin of ETEC

P- Pertussis

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO) Guidelines on Cholera: WHO Cholera Guidelines

choices.text: Intravenous antibiotics and possible surgical intervention

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presents with acute onset of eyelid swelling, redness, and pain around the eye, along with fever and limited eye movement. A CT scan reveals orbital swelling and possible involvement of the ethmoid sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the tissues surrounding the eye, including the eyelids, orbital fat, and muscles. It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.

  • Etiology:
    • Typically caused by bacterial infections, most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species.
    • Can also be a complication of sinus infections, especially from the ethmoid or maxillary sinuses.
  • Symptoms:
    • Rapidly progressive swelling of the eyelids and surrounding tissues.
    • Redness and warmth in the affected area.
    • Painful eye movements and possible reduced vision.
    • Fever and systemic symptoms may also be present.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical evaluation and history.
    • Imaging studies, such as CT scan or MRI, to assess the extent of infection and rule out other conditions.
    • Laboratory tests to identify the causative organism and determine antibiotic sensitivity.
  • Treatment:
    • Prompt administration of intravenous antibiotics to cover common pathogens.
    • Surgical intervention may be necessary to drain abscesses or remove any infected tissue if there is no improvement with antibiotics alone.
  • Complications:
    • Can lead to serious complications like vision loss, orbital abscess, or even meningitis if not treated promptly.

Topical antibiotics and warm compresses (Option A) and Oral antibiotics and analgesics (Option B) are inadequate for the severity of this condition and do not address the potential need for surgical intervention.

Observation and follow-up in 1-2 weeks (Option D) is inappropriate as orbital cellulitis requires immediate treatment to prevent serious complications.

choices.text: Most commonly seen in Bipolar 1 Mood Disorder
Cataplexy is one of the classical features seen in this condition
Benzodiazepines are the first line management for this condition
This condition has been discussed separately in DSM-5

questions.text: A case of 28 years old male brought to casualty with complaints of mutism, repeating same words after examiner's question and with abnormal posture. All complaints started since last 10 days. All of them are true regarding the clinical presentation except?
questions.solution:
Above clinical presentation is suggestive of Catatonia.

Catatonia- Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioral abnormalities that may include motoric immobility or excitement, profound negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech) or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

DSM-5 criteria for catatonia

Criteria A: three or more of the following symptoms

  • Stupor, no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment
  • Catalepsy: passive induction of posture against gravity
  • Waxy Flexibility: slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner
  • Mutism: no or very little verbal response to instructions or external stimuli
  • Negativism: opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli
  • Posturing: spontaneous and active maintenance of posturing against gravity
  • Mannerism: odd circumstantial caricature of normal actions
  • Stereotype: repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal directed movements
  • Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
  • Grimacing
  • Echolalia: mimicking another's speech
  • Echopraxia: mimicking another's movement

Catatonia is condition mostly seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Among inpatients with catatonia, 25 to 50 percent are related to mood disorders (e.g., major depressive episode, recurrent, with catatonic features), and approximately 10 percent are associated with schizophrenia.

Management

  • Benzodiazepine
  • Electroconvulsive Therapy
  • Anti-Psychotic/ Anti-Depressants
  • Treat the causative factor.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Catatonia- Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioral abnormalities that may include motoric immobility or excitement, profound negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech) or echopraxia (mimicry of movement)

choices.text: Referral to a specialist for biopsy

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presents with a single, painless ulcer on his genitalia that appeared about three weeks ago. The ulcer has a clean base and raised edges. He also reports swollen lymph nodes in the groin. The patient has no significant medical history and denies any recent sexual activity, although he admits to occasional unprotected sex. Based on the clinical presentation and the CDC guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of a painless ulcer (chancre) and regional lymphadenopathy is suggestive of primary syphilis. According to CDC guidelines, the appropriate next step is to perform serological testing for syphilis to confirm the diagnosis. Testing includes non-treponemal tests (e.g., RPR or VDRL) followed by treponemal tests (e.g., FTA-ABS) for confirmation.

Primary syphilis typically presents with:

  • A single, painless ulcer on genitalia
  • Clean base, raised edges
  • Swollen shotty lymph nodes
  • Spontaneously heals in 3-6 weeks.
  • Diagnosis- Dark-field microscopy, serological tests (RPR, VDRL, FTA-ABS)

Immediate initiation of oral azithromycin (Option A): Incorrect. While azithromycin has been studied for early syphilis, it is not the first-line treatment per CDC guidance. Starting azithromycin before confirming diagnosis can complicate case management and risk treatment failure or misdiagnosis

Immediate initiation of intravenous penicillin (Option C): Incorrect. Intravenous penicillin is valuable for neurosyphilis or ocular syphilis, but not recommended as initial empiric therapy. First-line management is based on diagnostic confirmation via serologic tests, not immediate IV treatment

Referral to a specialist for biopsy (Option D): Incorrect. A biopsy is not part of standard initial syphilis diagnosis; the CDC recommends serologic screening (nontreponemal and treponemal tests) as the primary diagnostic step.

Key Takeaway: A hard chancre is a hallmark of primary syphilis, and early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent the disease's progression.

Serological testing for syphilis is essential to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment. The CDC guidelines recommend starting with diagnostic tests to confirm syphilis rather than starting treatment immediately.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Syphilis Treatment Guidelines. CDC Syphilis Guidelines

Bohler-Brown splint for applying skin traction
Bohler-Brown splint for applying skeletal traction

questions.text: Identify the splint and choose correct option according to its indication:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Bohler-Brown splint for applying skeletal traction

Bohler-Braun splint: It has a number of pulleys (1-3) over which the traction cord passes while giving skeletal traction for different fractures. It is more convenient than Thomas splint since it has no ring. The ring of a Thomas splint is a common cause of discomfort, especially in elderly people. A Bohler-Braun splint has no inbuilt system of countertraction, hence it is not suitable for transportation.

Fig: Bohler Braun Splint

Thomas splint for applying skeletal traction (Option A) -: It is one of the commonest splints used in orthopaedic practice. It was devised by H.O. Thomas, initially for immobilisation for tuberculosis of the knee. It is now commonly used for the immobilisation and transportation of hip and thigh injuries.

Fig. Thomas splint

Cramer wire splint for splinting and transportation (Option D) - Cramer-wire splint: This splint is used for temporary splintage of fractures during transportation. It is made up of two thick parallel wires with interlacing wires. It can be bent into different shapes in order to immobilise different parts of the body.

Fig. Cramer splint

questions.text: Which of the following types of staphyloma commonly associated with high myopia?
questions.solution:
Types of staphyloma:

  1. Posterior Staphyloma
    • Location: Posterior pole of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: High myopia, degenerative conditions
    • Description: Localized protrusion at the back of the eye, often linked to high myopia and scleral thinning.
  2. Equatorial Staphyloma
    • Location: Equator of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: Myopia, scleral degeneration
    • Description: Outpouching around the equatorial region, characterized by scleral thinning and bulging.
  3. Anterior Staphyloma
    • Location: Anterior part of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: Corneal ectasia, thinning
    • Description: Protrusion at the front of the eye, associated with corneal thinning or ectasia.
  4. Intermediate Staphyloma
    • Location: Between anterior and posterior poles
    • Associated Conditions: Rare conditions
    • Description: A less common type occurring between the anterior and posterior poles, often with less specific characteristics.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
• Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.
  • This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Superfetation (Option A): Superfetation refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant. This is not applicable in the given scenario, as there is no indication of a second pregnancy occurring during an ongoing pregnancy.
  • Suppositious child (Option C): A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own. In the given scenario, there is no indication of false claims or substitution of the child, as DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. Therefore, suppositious child is not the appropriate term for this case.
  • Atavism (Option D): Atavism refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations. It is not applicable in the given scenario, as the issue at hand is related to the genetic paternity of the twins, rather than the reappearance of ancestral traits.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.

questions.text:
A patient met with RTA and developed knee pain with hemarthrosis. An MRI of the knee joint was done after 1 week which showed injury to posterior cruciate ligament and postero-lateral corner of the knee joint. Which clinical tests will be positive in this patient ?
1. DIAL test
2. Lachman test
3. Posterior drawer test
4. McMurray's test
questions.solution:
Dial Test

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnose posterolateral knee injury.
    • Differentiate between:
      • Isolated Posterolateral Corner (PLC) injury.
      • Combination of PLC and Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) injury.
  • Tibial External Rotation (Dial) Test:
    • Procedure:
      • Assess external rotation of the tibia on the femur at both 30 and 90 degrees of knee flexion.
      • The test can be performed with the patient either supine or prone.
    • Findings:
      • Isolated PLC Injury:
        • More than a 10-degree increase in external rotation compared to the contralateral side at 30 degrees of knee flexion, but not at 90 degrees.
      • PLC and PCL Injury:
        • Pathologic external rotation at 30 degrees of knee flexion.
        • Increased external rotation when the knee is flexed to 90 degrees.
  • For Isolated PCL Tear:
    • The posterior drawer test or sag test are more relevant.

(Option A and C) In this case both PCL and PLC are injured, hence both posterior drawer and DIAL test will be positive.

(Option B) - Lachman's test is most sensitive test for ACL injury.

(Option D) - McMurray's test is user for clinical examination in meniscus injuries.

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern shown in the image:
questions.solution:
• An arch fingerprint pattern is the simplest and least common type.
  • It appears as a continuous wave-like pattern without any deltas or cores. In an arch pattern, the ridges enter from one side of the fingerprint and exit from the opposite side, forming a slight upward or downward curve.

Incorrect Options:

  • Whorl (Option A): A whorl fingerprint pattern consists of circular or spiral ridges forming at least one complete circuit, and is characterized by two or more deltas-features not present in the provided image.
  • Composite (Option B): Composite patterns combine two or more primary fingerprint types (arches, loops, whorls), resulting in complex ridge arrangements. The image lacks such mixed structural features.
  • Loop (Option C): Loop patterns display one delta and a core, with ridges curving back to exit on the same side they entered. Those characteristics are absent in the image.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Arch appears as a continuous wave-like pattern without any deltas or cores. In an arch pattern, the ridges enter from one side of the fingerprint and exit from the opposite side, forming a slight upward or downward curve.

questions.text: It is widely considered in orthopaedic practice that Ilizarov's ring fixator is the final resort to many failed as well as complex primary fractures. All of the following are indications of Illizarov's ring fixator except:
questions.solution:
Pelvic external fixators are used for complex pelvic injuries and not Illizarov’s ring fixator.

Ilizarov Technique

Applications:

  1. Limb Lengthening: (Option D)
    • Useful for lengthening limbs, especially when shortening is accompanied by deformity.
    • The fixator assembly is designed to correct deformity and produce lengthening simultaneously.
    • Capable of massive limb lengthening (up to 18 inches).
    • Provides a stable biological environment for new bone formation at the lengthening site.
  2. Non-Union:
    • Effective for non-unions resistant to conventional treatments or those associated with deformity or shortening.
    • Can address non-unions requiring skin cover and bone grafting without staged surgeries.
  3. Deformity Correction:
    • Suitable for correcting both congenital and acquired deformities. (Option B)
  4. Osteomyelitis Treatment:
    • Allows for liberal excision of necrotic bone.
    • The resulting gap can be filled by transporting a segment of bone from either end.
  5. Arthrodesis: (Option A)
    • Achieved by "crushing" the articular surfaces together to stimulate union between opposing bones.

questions.text: Winking owl sign is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Bone to bone metastasis in vertebra presents as winking owl sign on Xray(1 pedicle is not visible).

Introduction to Spinal Tumors

  • Spine as a Site of Metastasis:
    • The spine frequently hosts metastases.
    • Certain tumors have a particular tendency to affect the spine, showing unique manifestations in the vertebrae.
  • Tumors of the Vertebral Body:
    • Histiocytosis X
    • Giant Cell Tumor
    • Chordoma
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Hemangioma
    • Metastatic Disease
    • Marrow Cell Tumors
  • Tumors of the Posterior Elements:
    • Aneurysmal Bone Cysts
    • Osteoblastoma
    • Osteoid Osteoma
  • Imaging Studies in Spinal Tumors
  • Radiographic Changes:
    • Most tumors are osteolytic and may not be visible on plain films until more than 30% of the vertebral body is destroyed.
    • Absence of a Pedicle: Identified as the "winking owl sign" on anteroposterior radiographs. (Options B)
    • Cortical Erosion or Expansion
    • Vertebral Collapse
  • Bone Scans:
    • Useful for detecting protracted back pain or night pain.
  • MRI:
    • Diagnostic Modality of Choice.
  • CT Scan:
    • Provides information on bony involvement and mechanical stability.
  • CT-Guided Needle Biopsy:
    • Often possible when the primary tumour is unknown.
    • May avoid the need for surgical open biopsy.

Spondylolisthesis (Option A) - Characteristic x-ray sign in spondylolisthesis is 'beheaded Scottish dog sign'.

Osteoporosis (Option C) - Characteristic x-ray findings in osteoporosis are 'biconcave / fish-mouth vertebrae'

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with decreased vision and photophobia in both eyes, several months after undergoing surgical repair for a penetrating injury in the right eye. On examination, bilateral anterior uveitis with signs of vitritis and choroiditis are observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmia

  • bilateral, granulomatous uveitis that occurs after trauma or surgery to one eye, leading to inflammation in the uninjured, or "sympathetic," eye.
  • It is an autoimmune response where the immune system attacks the uveal tissue of the unaffected eye following trauma to the other eye.

Etiology: Typically occurs after ocular trauma (e.g., penetrating injury) or ocular surgery. The exact mechanism is unclear but is believed to involve a hypersensitivity reaction to uveal antigens that are released from the injured eye and then recognized as foreign by the immune system.

Clinical Features:

  • Onset: Can occur weeks to months after the initial trauma or surgery.
  • Symptoms in Affected Eye:
    • Decreased vision
    • Redness
    • Pain
    • Photophobia
    • Floaters
  • Signs:
    • Bilateral uveitis (both anterior and posterior segments may be involved)
    • Vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous body)
    • Choroiditis (inflammation of the choroid)
    • Retinal edema
    • Possible optic nerve involvement

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Comprehensive eye examination showing bilateral uveitis with characteristic findings of sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • Imaging: OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography) and fundus photography may be used to assess retinal and choroidal involvement.
  • Exclusion of Other Causes: Important to rule out other causes of bilateral uveitis and intraocular inflammation.

Management:

  • Immediate Treatment: High-dose systemic corticosteroids are typically used to reduce inflammation and prevent further damage.
  • Additional Immunosuppressive Therapy: May be necessary for cases resistant to corticosteroids or to reduce the steroid dose.
  • Supportive Care: Includes managing symptoms and monitoring for complications.

Prognosis: With prompt and aggressive treatment, vision can often be preserved. However, if untreated, sympathetic ophthalmia can lead to significant visual impairment or blindness.


Complications: Include chronic uveitis, retinal detachment, and vision loss.

  • Sympathetic Ophthalmia (Option B): This condition is characterized by bilateral granulomatous uveitis occurring after trauma or surgery to one eye. The patient's history of ocular trauma followed by bilateral uveitis and vitritis aligns with this diagnosis.
  • Acute Anterior Uveitis (Option A): Typically unilateral and more associated with specific etiologies rather than a delayed onset after ocular trauma.
  • Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option C): Generally presents with dendritic corneal ulcers and may include anterior uveitis, but is not typically associated with bilateral uveitis following trauma.
  • Behçet's Disease (Option D): A systemic vasculitis that can indeed cause bilateral uveitis, but it usually presents along with systemic symptoms like recurrent oral and genital ulcers, and skin lesions.

questions.text: What is the ratio of breaths to chest compressions when performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation alone in an adult?
questions.solution:
Whether there are one or two rescuers, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breath for all persons is 30:2, i.e. 30 chest compressions for 2 breathing pauses, if no advanced airway is placed.


Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic medications should not be used in chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
• Pethidine (also known as meperidine) is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain management.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, pethidine should be avoided due to its active metabolite, normeperidine, which can accumulate and cause neurotoxicity.
  • Normeperidine can lead to central nervous system excitation, seizures, and other adverse effects, particularly in patients with impaired renal function.
  • Alternative opioids with shorter or no active metabolites, such as fentanyl or sufentanil, are preferred in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: What anaesthetic gas is in the blue conduit in OT?
questions.solution: Blue pipeline in OT delivers Nitrous Oxide

questions.text: Identify the image shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
T1-weighted imaging (T1WI) is a fundamental type of MRI sequence that provides information about tissue properties.

  1. Appearance:
    • Fat: Appears bright (high signal intensity) because fat has a short T1 relaxation time.
    • Water and fluid (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, cysts): Appears dark (low signal intensity) due to a longer T1 relaxation time.
    • Muscle, soft tissue, and gray matter: Intermediate signal intensity.
    • White matter: Slightly brighter than gray matter due to its fat content.
  2. Purpose:
    • Used for anatomical detail and structural imaging because it provides high contrast between different tissues.
    • Particularly useful for visualizing fat-containing tissues, detecting hemorrhage, and assessing the integrity of brain structures.
  3. Clinical Applications:
    • Brain MRI: Good for detecting anatomical abnormalities, brain structure, and some tumors (especially those with fat content).
    • Spine MRI: Helpful for assessing spinal anatomy and detecting changes in spinal cord structure.
    • Musculoskeletal MRI: Used to differentiate fat from other tissues and evaluate bone marrow, muscles, and tendons.
  4. Contrast Enhancement:
    • When gadolinium-based contrast agents are used, T1-weighted imaging is excellent for detecting areas of enhancement, which often correspond to regions of increased blood flow, inflammation, or breakdown of the blood-brain barrier (e.g., tumors, infections, active demyelinating lesions).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: T1-weighted MRI is a fundamental imaging technique, often used in conjunction with other MRI sequences, like T2-weighted or FLAIR, to give a comprehensive view of both normal anatomy and pathological changes.

questions.text: Black foot disease with peripheral neuropathy is seen in which metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.
  • It is a severe form of peripheral vascular disease in which blood vessels of the lower limb are severely damaged, eventually resulting in gangrene.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of arsenic, typically through contaminated drinking water or food, can lead to peripheral neuropathy and other health issues.

Incorrect Options:

Lead (Option B): Lead poisoning can lead to developmental delays, learning difficulties, behavior problems, and impaired growth. In adults, it can cause neurological symptoms such as headaches, memory loss, and concentration problems, as well as abdominal pain and reproductive issues. It is not associated with Blackfoot disease.

Mercury (Option C): The symptoms and effects of mercury poisoning depend on its form. Methylmercury, found in contaminated fish and seafood, primarily affects the nervous system and can cause developmental issues in children, as well as neurological and cardiovascular problems in adults. It is not associated with Blackfoot disease.

Cadmium (Option D): Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys, causing kidney damage and Itai-Itai disease in Japan. It is not associated with Blackfoot disease, which instead results from chronic arsenic exposure.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following MRI sequences best depicts the edematous changes in the brain parenchyma?
questions.solution:
FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) is a specialized MRI sequence designed to suppress the signals from fluids, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), making it particularly useful in brain imaging. It is a type of T2-weighted imaging with modifications that "null" or remove the bright signal from free fluid, making abnormal areas stand out more clearly.

Appearance:

  • CSF and free fluids: Appears dark (signal is suppressed).
  • Abnormal fluid or pathology (e.g., edema, inflammation) Appears bright, helping to identify lesions near or within fluid-filled spaces.
  • Gray and white matter: Intermediate signal intensities similar to T2-weighted images.
  • Lesions: Pathological tissues like tumors, infections, and demyelinating lesions typically appear bright against a darker background.

Purpose:

  • FLAIR is particularly useful for detecting lesions that are near or adjacent to CSF-filled areas, such as those in the brain parenchyma.
  • It is excellent for evaluating white matter diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS) or areas of edema, ischemia, or gliosis

Clinical Applications:

  • Brain MRI: FLAIR is commonly used to identify abnormalities that are hard to detect with conventional T2-weighted images because of interference from bright CSF. It is especially useful for:
  • Detecting subtle white matter lesions (e.g., in MS).
  • Identifying infarcts and stroke regions.
  • Evaluating brain tumors and the associated edema or infiltration
  • Detecting subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) after the acute phase
  • Spinal Cord MRI: FLAIR can also be used to detect inflammatory or demyelinating lesions within the spinal cord, though its use is more limited in the spine.

Fig: FLAIR MRI sequence showing cerebral edema

KEY TAKEAWAYS: FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) is a specialized MRI sequence designed to suppress the signals from fluids, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), making it particularly useful in brain imaging. It is a type of T2-weighted imaging with modifications that "null" or remove the bright signal from free fluid, making abnormal areas stand out more clearly.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of iodinated contrast medium?
questions.solution:
Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a reaction seen with gadolinium contrast agents not iodinated contrast medium

CT contrast agents (specifically iodinated contrast agents) are generally safe but can have side effects, which range from mild to severe. These side effects are typically related to the body's response to the iodine in the contrast material.

questions.text: Which of the following agent is used as contrast in CT scan?
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast agents are commonly used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans to enhance the visibility of certain tissues and blood vessels. These contrast agents contain iodine, which is highly radiopaque, meaning it absorbs X-rays effectively. This makes structures with the contrast agent appear brighter on the CT images, improving differentiation between normal and abnormal tissues.

Types:

  • Non-ionic contrast (commonly used due to fewer side effects).
  • Ionic contrast (less commonly used, can have more side effects).

Option B,C and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Iodinated contrast agents are commonly used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans to enhance the visibility of certain tissues and blood vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following features on ultrasound help in identifying the gall bladder calculi?
questions.solution:
Posterior acoustic shadowing (or simply acoustic shadowing) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves encounter a structure that strongly attenuates or blocks the transmission of sound. This typically happens with dense structures such as bone, calcifications, or stones (e.g., gallstones or kidney stones).

Because the sound waves are either absorbed or reflected by these structures, very little or no sound energy reaches deeper tissues, resulting in a dark or hypoechoic shadow on the ultrasound image behind (posterior to) the attenuating structure.

This shadowing effect is useful in diagnostic imaging, as it can help identify and characterize solid, dense objects, such as stones, calcifications, or foreign bodies.

Posterior acoustic enhancement (Option A) (also known as through transmission) is an ultrasound phenomenon that occurs when sound waves pass through a structure with low attenuation, such as fluid-filled areas (e.g., cysts, the urinary bladder, or gallbladder). As the sound waves travel through these structures, they lose very little energy.

On the ultrasound image, this results in an area of increased brightness or echogenicity immediately posterior (deeper) to the low-attenuating structure. This phenomenon helps differentiate fluid-filled structures from solid masses, as solid masses tend to attenuate sound waves more and would not exhibit posterior enhancement.

Reverberation (Option B) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves bounce back and forth between two strong reflectors, producing multiple equally spaced echoes on the image. This creates the appearance of repeated structures that are not actually present, often seen in fluid-filled areas like the bladder or cysts.

Ring Down artifact (Option D) in radiology, particularly in ultrasound imaging, refers to a type of reverberation artifact caused by trapped gas bubbles. It produces a continuous, solid streak or band of echoes extending down from the source of the bubbles.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Posterior acoustic shadowing (or simply acoustic shadowing) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves encounter a structure that strongly attenuates or blocks the transmission of sound. This typically happens with dense structures such as bone, calcifications, or stones (e.g., gallstones or kidney stones).

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Incorrect Options:

Morphine (Option A): Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. In morphine poisoning, you’d expect pinpoint pupils-though rare mydriasis can occur later due to hypoxia or acidosis-but dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.

Cannabis (Option B): Cannabis may cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Common effects are dry mouth, red eyes, and occasionally dilated pupils with edibles-but the full picture described doesn't match cannabis.

Alcohol (Option D): Alcohol intoxication may lead to altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it typically causes miosis or normal pupils, not dry skin or dilated pupils. There are no anticholinergic effects like those seen with Datura.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic symptoms, including dry skin, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium.

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
• Hyperthermia refers to elevated body temperature. In chronic starvation, the body's metabolic rate decreases, and thermoregulation mechanisms work to conserve heat rather than generate excess heat. Therefore, hyperthermia is not a characteristic change seen in chronic starvation.

Chronic Starvation causes the development of the following changes in the order mentioned below:

  • Loss of well-being, hunger, and hunger pains.
  • Mental and physical lethargy and easy fatigue.
  • Progressive loss of weight which is rapid in the first six months.
  • Polyuria
  • Increasing wasting, the body weight is reduced by about 40% of the normal.
  • Pigmentation and anemia.
  • Hypothermia and not Hyperthermia; peripheral vascular stasis in cold and hypotension.

Incorrect Options:

Exhaustion (Option B): Chronic starvation leads to the depletion of energy reserves in the body, resulting in fatigue, weakness, and exhaustion.

Heart atrophy (Option C): In chronic starvation, the body conserves energy by reducing its metabolic rate, which leads to muscle wasting-including the heart muscle-causing heart atrophy.

Hypotension (Option D): Hypotension refers to low blood pressure. In chronic starvation, reduced blood volume and diminished cardiac output contribute to decreased blood pressure.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In chronic starvation, the body's metabolic rate decreases, and thermoregulation mechanisms work to conserve heat rather than generate excess heat. Therefore, hyperthermia is not a characteristic change seen in chronic starvation.

questions.text: 45-year-old male brought to casualty after he met with a Road Traffic Accident followed by Minor bruises over temporal region and maxillary bone. On detailed evaluation, you found that he was driving in intoxicated state with last intake 12 hours back. In the ER, he gets fits(seizure) for first time. He was restless and had perspiration all over his body. NCCT suggestive of no significant abnormality. What can be the reason for seizure in this patient?
questions.solution:
45-year-old male met with an accident, under intoxicated state with Last intake of Alcohol being 12 hours back a Bruises over Temporal region and Maxillary region with NCCT is suggestive of no significant Abnormality ruling out Head Injury.(Option A)

Alcohol intoxication manifest as slurring of speech, motor in coordination, judgement impairment, nystagmus, coma and death and not present with seizures.(Option B)

Alcohol Withdrawal Seizure- history suggestive of Alcohol intake and RTA under intoxication without significant head injury & last intake being 12 hours back Alcohol withdrawal usually starts after 6 hours more the withdrawal duration, more the complicated withdrawal withdrawal seizures.(Option C)

Hierarchical presentation of Alcohol withdrawal.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Delirium Tremens (agitation, clouding of consciousness, disorientation, delusions, hallucinations, etc.), manifests within the first 24 to 48 hours but can be manifested even after 72 hours to 1 week of Alcohol cessation. Resolve on its own in 10 days

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate 30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?
ABG - Metabolic acidosis
1. Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL
2. Blood Urea - 100 mg/dL
3. Creatinine - 3.4 mg/dL
4. Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomepizole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.
